column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174077,2016,The drug and the cell,English,Faculty of Science,,['prof. dr. R.J. Kok'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After this course you will be able to:

1. Describe the interaction between ligands (drugs, substrates) and their macromolecular target (receptor, enzyme); both qualitatively - and quantitatively (ligand binding and enzyme kinetics, inhibition)
2. Describe the role of membrane receptors and other receptors involved in signal transduction cascades in the cell in health and disease
3. Describe cellular processes related to the use of novel drugs, like RNAi
4. Perform protein analysis techniques like SDS-PAGE, Western blotting
5. Use protein databases, DNA databases, disease related databases, and search for gene or protein homology.
6.  Write a receptor report about a receptor and its interaction with a specific drug and you will present these data in an oral presentation.
7. Write a short research article, according to the standards used for scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals like ‘Nature’ and ‘Science’

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The       course       consists       of       two       main       project       assignments,       1)       the       Receptor       Report,       in       which       you       will       work       in       small       teams       of       2       to       4       students,       and       2)       the       Short       Research       Article       that       you       will       prepare       on       your       own.

The       required       background       knowledge       to       complete       the       assignments       will       be       collected       through       lectures,       workshops,       practical       assignments       and       laboratory       experiments.

The       final       grade       is       based       on       the       assessment       of       the       report       and       the       article,       the       presentations       of       the       different       projects,       and       the       grade       for       the       individual       exam.

You will discover how drugs act within the cell, and in particular how they act at the molecular level. Basically, there are two kinds of drugs against disease, these are the ‘small molecule’ drugs (a low molecular weight organic compound, typically between 300-700 Da, e.g. aspirin) and the ‘biopharmaceuticals’ (a high molecular weight biomolecule, like a vaccine, a therapeutic antibody, or RNAi).

Starting       with       the       ‘key-and-lock’       model,       you       will       learn       about       the       role       of       ligands       and       receptors,       and       about       the       interaction       of       drugs       with       their       molecular       targets       in       the       cell.       You       will       get       familiarized       with       drugs       like       growth-factor       receptor       antagonists,       signal       transduction       pathway       inhibitors       and       enzyme       activity       blocking       agents,       as       well       as       with       drug       targeting       approaches       to       improve       the       efficacy       and/or       selectivity       of       drugs.
After       this       course       you       will       be       able       to:

1. Describe the interaction between ligands (drugs, substrates) and their macromolecular target (receptor, enzyme); both qualitatively - and quantitatively (ligand binding and enzyme kinetics, inhibition)
2. Describe the role of membrane receptors and other receptors involved in signal transduction cascades in the cell in health and disease
3. Describe cellular processes related to the use of novel drugs, like RNAi
4. Perform protein analysis techniques like SDS-PAGE, Western blotting
5.       Use       protein       databases,       DNA       databases,       disease       related       databases,       and       search       for       gene       or       protein       homology.
6.  Write a receptor report about a receptor and its interaction with a specific drug and you will present these data in an oral presentation.

7.       Write       a       short       research       article,       according       to       the       standards       used       for       scientific       publications       in       peer-reviewed       journals       like       ‘Nature’       and       ‘Science’

For       this       course       you       need       the       book       ‘Molecular       Biology       of       the       Cell’,       5<sup>th</sup>       revised       edition,       by       Bruce       Alberts       e.a.       (2007).
Dr. R.J. Kok. email: R.J.Kok@uu.nl and Mw. Dr. M. Slijper, email: M.Slijper@uu.nl

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Familiarize students with interdisciplinary approaches to scientific research
Prepare the students to cooperate and communicate at an academic level outside their own area of expertise
Broaden the students global awareness, in particular the connections between science and society
Stimulate the development of networking and leadership skills
Provide the students with international experience</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: <tr height=""22"">

column7: The interdisciplinary module of science honours academy involves all the science honours students working together on projects and activities in interdisciplinary groups.  The module programme consists of several activities offered in a modular format for which the students receive 7.5 ECTS in total. The aim is to acquaint the science honours students with the three levels of interdisciplinarity: general practices, education and research. This is achieved by a core set of compulsory activities including organisation and participation in symposia on interdisciplinary research topics, skills workshops, a trip to internationally renown universities or laboratories, and interdisciplinary group projects on on topics ranging from great societal challenges (food, energy, health), development, evolution and complex systems in the context of UU focus areas. The language of communication in the interdisciplinary component is English.

column5: </tr>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171701,2016,The legitimation of politics,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. W. F. Kalf'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Overdragen van kennis       en       inzicht       over       de       legitimering       van       de       politiek       op       mondiaal       niveau.
Het aanleren en     versterken     van     vaardigheden     in     systematische     politiek-filosofische     analyse     van     economische     instituties     en     systemen.
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De cursus behandelt     de     verschillende     theorieën     en     debatten     die     worden     gevoerd     over     de     legitimering     van     politiek     buiten     de     grenzen     van     de     natiestaat.     Kan     het     klassieke     sociaal     contract     ook     werken     op     mondiaal     niveau?     Deze     algemene     vraag     werpt     een     aantal     meer     specifieke     vragen     op:     Kunnen     theorieën     die     het     gezag     van     de     staat     legitimeren     naar     mondiaal     niveau     worden     doorgetrokken? https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170924,2016,The multicultural society,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['drs. G.B.M. Dielissen', 'E.Y. Driel, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The course aims to introduce students to the study of a current social issue: the multicultural society.
More specifically, it is aimed that students should:

column5: Accumulate knowledge on the main problems regarding citizenship in multicultural societies and on the ways the organization of citizenship is connected to making claims about cultural diversity.
Be able to relate these insights in studying a specific case.

column3: Skills explicitly trained in this course regard:

column5: The collection and analysis of relevant information regarding the case study.
The presentation and defense, both orally and in writing, of the analysis done.
The process of working together in project-groups to effectively plan and carry this plan into effect.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: A society is named 'multicultural' when it is comprised of various ethnic populations and/or various nationalities. Western 'multicultural' societies include people from the Mediterranean countries who came during the 1960s and 1970s as so-called 'guest-workers'. In the 1970 and 1980s people from former colonies and asylum-seekers also found their way to European countries. One of the main challenges for multicultural societies is to develop social cohesion out of this diversity, a process that doesn't go without tensions and conflicts. While many newcomers succeeded in integrating into their new homeland without neglecting their cultural identity, conflicts between insiders and outsiders didn't disappear. Inclusion and exclusion as well as integration and separation are processes social scientists concentrate on.

The course addresses in addition to migration, issues of ethnicity and identity formation, the Rise of Extreme Right and Populism in Western societies, as well as the Challenge of Islam and tries to explain the radicalization of segments of the second generation muslim population. In tutorials studens present and illustrate their take on the readings and lectures and analyse contemporary topical films and documentaries in the light of theoretical concepts discussed. The course is centered around the book International Migration: Globalization's Last Frontier, Global Issues. Additional readings taken from peer reviewed journals complement the book. Assessment takes place on the basis of a midterm exam and a group research paper. The paper has to be presented in class.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174929,2016,The Senses, Art and Visual Culture: Theory",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. S. van der Meulen', 'M. Groenen, MA']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After successful completion of this course, the student has:
•          developed a critical understanding of theories and philosophies dealing with visuality and the hierarchy of the senses
•          developed a critical understanding of theories of visual culture and the relation they has with the visual arts
•          practiced with making critical understanding of visual culture theories and theories, criticism and philosophies dealing with visuality, the senses and the hierarchy of the senses

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The aim of this course is to make students familiar with and learn them to look critically at theories of visuality and theories that consider the senses, the importance of sight and the anti-ocular impulse. Today sight seems to be the most importance sense in our culture. But has this, from a historical point of view, always been so? Which theories and philosophies have questioned the dominance of sight and why? How has modern and contemporary art dealt with its own historically grown inclinations towards the eye? We will be considering ideas developed by philosophers such as Rene Descartes, Maurice Merleau-Ponty, Jean Baudrillard, Guy Debord; psychoanalysts such as Jacques Lacan and look at art from amongst others Gustave Courbet, impressionists, Marcel Duchamp, Jasper Johns, Andy Warhol, Donald Judd, Bruce Nauman, Martin Kippenberger…    </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173310,2016,The World, the Text and the Critic",English,Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. K. Driscoll', 'prof. dr. A. Rigney']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This introductory course offers a survey of different understandings of cultural criticism and of different practices of critical reading; it also aims to develop students' ability to engage critically with particular works of literature. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This seminar is inspired by the idea of cultural criticism as put forward by Edward Said in his book The World, the Text, and the Critic (1983). It aims to develop your awareness of the multiple ways in which literature can offer a creative response to the world in which it is written and read. How does literature offer a resource for understanding the world? How have modern cultural theorists thought about the potential of literature to provide insight into the ways of the world and ideas about how it might become different? How have critics gone to work in articulating and making visible this potential? And finally, what is the future of cultural criticism and of 'experts' in the age of new media?

Focussing on the work of major practitioners, the course will explore these questions. We will examine long-term changes (since c.1800) in the concept of literature and culture, and shifting attitudes to the role of the critic in an age of democratisation. You will be asked to participate actively in the form of class assignments; you will complete the course by writing an essay demonstrating your own ability to read critically.

This course provides understanding of the public role of the 'expert' critic; as such it contributes to the self-understanding of the students as academically-trained literary 'experts' as well as enhancing their competence in the practice of critical reading and writing.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course introduces students to the scientific study of language. It provides an introduction to core concepts in the areas of syntax, morphology, phonology and phonetics, aiming at a sophisticated understanding of native speakers' unconscious knowledge of the structure of English words and sentences, and a basic understanding of the way in which this knowledge is acquired.  Students are familiarised with linguistic methods of data analysis, including the analysis of speech and corpus data, and acquire research writing skills. Students learn to write a research plan (200 words), a methodology section (500 words), and a research proposal (700 words). On the basis of a practical research project.

column3: During the speakers' seminar, which is organized biweekly at the Institute for Theoretical Physics, international experts will present contemporary research. The colloquium has to be attended at least 18 times in order to pass. Even though the colloquium speakers are well aware that master students make up a considerable fraction of their audience, the level of the colloquium is often unavoidably high. In order to optimise the student's benefit and understanding of the colloquia, a preparatory presentation by an ITP staff member will (often) be organised in which background information, history of the subject, or other relevant material will be informally discussed with the students. Attending this meeting, which will be scheduled at 15.00h just prior to the colloquium in room MG 401, is highly recommended but not compulsory. More details will be announced by email in due time.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course teaches you to develop and analyze mathematical models for biological processes. Almost all examples come from ecology, and most classical models in ecology will be “re-developed”. As similar models for population dynamics are also used in other areas of biology, the course is also open to students not majoring in ecology.

The course starts with 5 weeks of lectures and (computer)practicals.  We will teach you a stepwise approach to develop mathematical models.  Models will be analyzed by phase plane methods, steady state analysis, and computer simulation.  Students will become able to develop their own models, and be able to evaluate and analyze existing mathematical models.

The second part of the course consists of a journal club, guest lectures, and a project.  In the journal club we read and discuss several classical and/or recent papers in theoretical ecology.  The guest lectures illustrate how ecologists and evolutionary biologists use mathematical modeling in their current research.  The project allows you to perform your own research.  We ask you to repeat the work of a recent paper and to extend this with ideas of your own. The last day of the course students present their results in a symposium and a paper.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Systeembiologie (jaar 1) is verplicht en Ecologie (jaar 1) is aanbevolen
Deze cursus behoort tot de studieadviespaden Organismen, ecosystemen en biodiversiteit en Theoretische Biologie & Bioinformatica.

Theoretisch onderzoek speelt een belangrijke rol in de ecologie. De cursus behandelt een groot aantal eenvoudige en een aantal gecompliceerde modellen om te laten zien hoe men met een dergelijke formele behandeling ecologische processen kan beschrijven en leren begrijpen. Studenten worden vertrouwd gemaakt met het opstellen en analyseren van wiskundige modellen. Theoretische ecologische modellen zouden na deze cursus niet langer als ‘black box’ beschouwd mogen worden. Resultaten van modellen, en hun eventuele ecologische consequenties, moeten kritisch gewogen worden aan de hand van de inhoud, de complexiteit, de realiteit, en het formalisme van het model.

In het onderdeel ‘modellering van populatiedynamica’ worden bekende modellen uit de theoretische ecologie opnieuw afgeleid. Door modellen zelf af te leiden uit eenvoudige biologische aannames leert de student dergelijke modellen kritisch te beschouwen en doet de student ervaring op met het zelf ontwikkelen van wiskundige modellen. De klassieke modellen voor de groei van populaties, roofdier-prooisystemen, concurrentie, en metapopulaties komen allen aan de orde. De student leert de resultaten verkregen met dergelijke modellen vertalen naar een biologische interpretatie (totaal 4 weken).

In het onderdeel ‘modellering van populatiedynamica’ worden bekende modellen uit de theoretische ecologie opnieuw afgeleid. Door modellen zelf af te leiden uit eenvoudige biologische aannames leert de student dergelijke modellen kritisch te beschouwen en doet de student ervaring op met het zelf ontwikkelen van wiskundige modellen. De klassieke modellen voor de groei van populaties, roofdier-prooisystemen, concurrentie, en metapopulaties komen allen aan de orde. De student leert de resultaten verkregen met dergelijke modellen vertalen naar een biologische interpretatie (totaal 6 weken, afgesloten met een tentamen).

Tijdens de tweede helft van de cursus lezen en bespreken we een aan klassieke en recente artikelen en zijn er een aantal gastcolleges van ecologen die zowel experimenten doen als modellen gebruiken. Dit wordt afgesloten met een tentamen. Daarnaast werk je in een kleine groep aan een groot project dat doorlopen wordt aan de hand van een recente wetenschappelijke publicatie. In deze grote opdracht leer je deze kennis in praktijk brengen, primaire literatuur lezen, en doorloop je de onderzoekcyclus van vraagstelling, naar onderzoek, naar het presenteren van je resultaten (totaal 4 weken, afgesloten met een symposium en schriftelijk verslag in het Engels).

Nieuwe stof wordt uitgelegd in hoorcolleges en geoefend in werkcolleges en computerpractica. We lezen en bespreken klassieke wetenschappelijke artikelen. In week 7-10 doorloop je de onderzoekcyclus en wordt zo zelfstandig mogelijk aan een groot project gewerkt. Daarnaast wordt tijd gereserveerd voor zelfstudie.

Het eindcijfer is een gewogen gemiddelde over de drie onderdelen. Voor de practica zelf krijg je geen cijfer, de deelname aan de practica is niet verplicht. In de praktijk blijken de practica essentieel voor een voldoende begrip van de stof.
Tijdens de cursus krijg je actuele informatie via Blackboard en/of http://tbb.bio.uu.nl/rdb/te
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174681,2016,Core Theory: Critical Terms for Literary Study,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. S.A. Pieterse'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Deze cursus wil studenten leren om:

a. de gemaakte keuzes in bestaand letterkundig en cultuurhistorisch onderzoek theoretisch en methodisch te wegen, dat wil zeggen te reflecteren op de relatie tussen de conceptuele en methodische keuzes en de resultaten van het onderzoek;
b. een uiteenzetting te geven over de belangrijke thema’s in theoretische en methodische debatten op het terrein van de eigen specialisatie en daarin een eigen standpunt te bepalen;
c. te begrijpen hoe die debatten zich verhouden tot een grotere geesteswetenschappelijke context.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In deze cursus lezen studenten enkele cruciale literatuur- en cultuurwetenschappelijke publicaties uit binnen en buitenland  en leren ze hoe te reflecteren op de gemaakte theoretische en methodische keuzes. In een referaat bespreken zij één toegewezen publicatie. In de eindnota positioneren zij zichzelf ten opzichte van een breder theoretisch en methodisch debat.

Om belangrijke theoretische begrippen scherp te krijgen, wordt ook iedere week lemma's uit het handboek Critical Terms for Literary Study besproken. Belangrijke theoretisch begrippen die in ieder geval aan de orde komen zijn:Interpretatie (gerelateerd aan close-, distant- en surface reading), Ideologie (gerelateerd aan de literaire canon, klasse en imperialisme/nationalisme). De methodische discussie zal worden toegespitst op de vraag hoe de omvang van een corpus de representativiteit van een onderzoek mede bepaalt. En ook: wordt de vraag groter en relevanter naarmate het corpus groter wordt? Wanneer wel en niet? En welke rol kunnen digitale middelen hierbij spelen?</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The general objectives of the internship is to get to know the field of dermatology in practice, refresh and expand previously acquired knowledge and skills and apply these in the clinical setting. After the completion of the internship Dermatology the intern should be able to take a complete history and conduct dermatological examinations. The intern also has to be able to come to a differential diagnosis, recognize the most common dermatological and venereal clinical pictures and should have gained insight in the diagnostics and therapeutic treatment options.
The duration of the internship is two weeks preceded by the connected preparatory course Dermatology of two weeks. The preparatory course consists of interactive lectures in small groups.
The internship Dermatology directly follows after the preparatory course Dermatology in master year 2.

Many titles from the general mandatory book list are relevant for this internship, in particular “Dermatologie en venereology in de praktijk”, A. de Groot en J. Toonstra. This Dutch written book will be mandatory from 2016. The present mandatory book is Dermatology, David J. Gawkrodger.

The course book dermatology and the ‘Manual Internship Dermatology year 5’ contain a wealth of information about the organization and content of the preparatory course, the internship and the internship placements. The course book, the manual and the portfolio have been placed on Blackboard and are also available from Willy’s Winkeltje.
The final grades for the theoretical course and the internship are separate.
The final grade for the preparatory theoretical course comprises:
All grades must be of sufficient level in order to pass the theoretical course.
The final grade for the internship comprises:
There are three additional requirements in order to pass the internship:
- Professional behaviour should be of sufficient level
- 2 brief practical assessments Clinical Consult and 1 brief practical assessment Technical Skill need to have been conducted

The final assessment consists of the separate assessment moments described above. According to the rules of the exam commission a weighted average grade will be calculated and the grade will be rounded up to one digit after the decimal point.

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het doel van het coschap KNO is om theoretische kennis uit te breiden en het vak KNO in de praktijk te leren. Een aantal voor het vak KNO-heelkundige specifieke vaardigheden zoals onderzoeken, diagnostische methoden en behandelingen wordt geleerd.

Het co-assistentschap KNO-heelkunde duurt in totaal vier weken. Deze vier weken zijn opgesplitst in een blokweek en drie weken kliniek. Tijdens de blokweek wordt u voorbereid op de kliniek door middel van KNO-casuïstiek (COO), Meet-the-Expert- bijeenkomsten over basale KNO en audiometrie, en een practicum Anatomie. Zo krijgt u de kans om in één week de basale kennis van het KNO specialisme op te frissen. Zelfstudie is vereist.

De blokweek wordt afgesloten met een bloktoets over basale KNO. Deze toets telt mee (gewogen factor) in uw eindbeoordeling. De blokweek dient u met een voldoende beoordeling af te ronden, alvorens u het klinische coschap van 3 weken kunt volgen.  Het coschap KNO kan zowel in het UMC Utrecht als in geaffilieerde ziekenhuizen worden gevolgd.
In het tweede jaar van de masteropleiding CRU2006.
Leerboek Keel-, Neus- en Oorheelkunde, onder redactie van E.H.Huizing en G.B. Snow. Uitgeverij Bohn, Stafleu & van Loghum. Laatste druk.
Zakboek Keel- en Neus- en Oorheelkunde, onder redactie van P. van der Broek en L. Feenstra. Uitgeverij Acco Leuven/Leusen. Laatste druk. (Aanbevolen)

De Handleiding ‘Blokweek KNO en Co-assistentschap KNO-heelkunde’ en de Portfolio Module bevatten een scala aan algemene organisatorische en inhoude­lijke informatie betreffende het coschap en de stageplaatsen. De Handleiding en de Portfolio module zijn verkrijgbaar via Willy’s win­keltje of via Blackboard en dienen in bezit te zijn van de student bij aanvang van de blokweek. Tevens ontvangt de student bij aanvang van de blokweek via het onderwijssecretariaat de meest actuele informatie, de roosters en een activiteitenschema.
Toetsing vindt plaats in het UMC Utrecht en geaffilieerde ziekenhuizen.

Het eindcijfer co-schap KNO is een gewogen gemiddelde cijfer (afgerond 1 decimaal achter de komma) en bestaat uit vier toetsmomenten. Elk toetsmoment telt mee, met een gewogen factor, voor het eindcijfer co-schap.

Indien een andere (of extra) co-schap plaats gewenst is in binnen- en/of buitenland, dan moet de student dit zelf regelen. Voor toestemming heeft de student een (schriftelijk) bewijs van het beoogde ziekenhuis/de opleider nodig. Samen met een volledig ingevulde aanvraag ‘binnen/buitenlands co-­schap’ (verkrijgbaar bij het onderwijssecretariaat KNO: d.houtkamp@umcutrecht.nl; telefoonnummer 088 7556644) levert de student beide in bij het onder­wijssecretariaat KNO. De onderwijscoördinator KNO UMC Utrecht geeft uiteindelijk goedkeuring.
Let op: de blokweek KNO voorafgaand aan het klinisch co-assistentschap is een verplicht onderdeel en kan alleen gevolgd worden in het UMC Utrecht.

Indien de student een aangevraagd co-assistentschap in een niet-geaffilieerd ziekenhuis maar in Nederland/België/Luxemburg volgt, wordt de student door de opleider daar beoordeeld op vakkennis, drie korte praktijkbeoordelingen, patiëntverslagen en professioneel gedrag. Hiervoor worden de gebruikeljke beoordelingsformulieren gebruikt. Het eindgesprek en het eindcijfer co-schap worden op het eindbeoordelingsformulier daar door de opleider afgetekend. Het eindbeoordelingsformulier, inclusief formulier van professioneel gedrag, worden daarna bij het onderwijssecretariaat KNO ingeleverd.

Indien de student een aangevraagd buitenlands co-assistentschap volgt, wordt de student daar beoordeeld op vakkennis, korte praktijkbeoordelingen, patiëntverslagen en professioneel gedrag. Hiervoor worden de Engelstalige beoordelingsformulieren gebruikt (verkrijgbaar bij onderwijs-secretariaat KNO). Het eindcijfer co-schap op het eindbeoordelingsformulier wordt niet in het buitenlandse ziekenhuis afgetekend.Na terugkomst levert de student binnen twee weken alle Engelstalige beoordelingen plus een plaatsvervangende opdracht in bij het onderwijssecretariaat KNO. De plaatsvervangende opdracht wordt beoordeeld door de onderwijscoördinator KNO UMC Utrecht. Alle beoordelingen samen (buitenland én UMC Utrecht) bepalen uiteindelijk het eindcijfer co-schap.
Het eindcijfer co-schap wordt dus bepaald door de onderwijscoördinator KNO UMC Utrecht. Dit wordt vastgelegd op het eindbeoordelingsformulier co-assistentschap KNO CRU.
Coördinator:         Mw. drs I. Ligtenberg-van der Drift, KNO-arts UMC Utrecht I.Ligtenberg-vanderdrift@umcutrecht.nl

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The objective of the internship is to learn the profession of ophthalmology in practice. Knowledge and skills acquired in the first three years of the medical program should be multiplied and applied in the context of the future professional practice. Interns should also learn to work with a professional attitude. The requirements Ophthalmology from the Blueprint 2001 are listed in the manual of the internship Ophthalmology. These provide  an overview of the skills and knowledge of examinations and diseases the intern must possess.  The intern has to take history with the list of complaints of the Blueprint in mind and is responsible of keeping these lists during the internship. The supervisor will discuss this list during the mid-term portfolio interview and final interview.

The ophthalmology internship takes 4 weeks, of which the first two weeks consist of course training in the UMC. These course weeks consist of theoretical and practical peer group sessions and an anatomy lab session. The course-weeks Ophthalmology are both an addition to the course ‘Brain, senses and Movement III’ in year 2 and a preparation for the 2-week internship in Ophthalmology.

column4: Ailments of the front section of the eye and skills have been covered in “Brain, Senses and Movement III”. During the Ophthalmology course weeks the back section of the eye, the orbita and traumatology will also be discussed. The course weeks will be concluded with a written test on eye impediments. The grade of the test will make up 30% of the final assessment of the internship.The book Leerboek oogheelkunde. red. Tan, H. / Pol,           B.A.E. van der / Stilma, J.S. or The book “Practical Ophthalmology” (2008, 2nd reviewed edition, Stilma, Voorn) will have to be studied in its entirety for this test.

The patient-bound internship of 2 weeks follows on the course weeks and can be followed in the UMC Utrecht or in the affiliated hospitals. The internship includes placements in outpatient wards, clinical wards, operation theatres and function departments.
Place of the internship within the curriculum
Leerboek oogheelkunde. red. Tan, H. / Pol,       B.A.E. van der / Stilma, J.S.
Oogheelkunde, J.S. Stilma T.B. Voorn, 2008, 2e herziene druk, serie Praktische Huisartsen Geneeskunde, Bohn Stafleu van Loghem.
The final grade is composed of 4 test moments:
-          written test at the eind of the course weeks before the internship (30%)
-          final interview (week 4) on the basis of the portfolio, list of attendance and list of procedures according to the Blueprint (40%)
Professional conduct will be assessed to be as “sufficient”, “needs attention” or as ” not sufficient”.
Coördinator: Dr. N.H. ten Dam-van Loon, tel 088-7557880, e-mail P.Fernhout@umcutrecht.nl

column4: · Studenten kunnen mondeling en schriftelijk reflecteren op theorie en praktijk van de wetenschapsbeoefening binnen hun eigen specialisme of TCS-hoofdrichting en daarbij op academische wijze gebruik maken    van concepten en redeneringen ontleend aan wetenschapsfilosofie, wetenschapsgeschiedenis en kritische wetenschapsstudies.

·  Studenten kunnen deze reflectie op eigen specialisme verbinden met debatten over theoretische en methodologische grondslagen van de geesteswetenschappen en kennis over de bredere wetenschappelijke    en maatschappelijke contexten waarbinnen de geesteswetenschappen functioneren.

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus maken         gevorderde         bachelor         studenten         geesteswetenschappen         (gw)         nader         kennis         met         discussies         over         wetenschap         in         het         algemeen         en         over         gw         in         het         bijzonder.         Zij         schrijven         tijdens         de         cursus         een         aantal         beschouwingen         over         de         wetenschapsbeoefening         binnen         hun         eigen         specialisme         en         maken         daarbij         gebruik         maken         concepten         en         redeneringen         uit         (1)         wetenschapsfilosofie,         (2)         wetenschapsgeschiedenis         en         (3)         kritische         wetenschapsstudies.         Uitgangspunt         van         de         cursus         is         de         diversiteit         van         vakgebieden         en         specialismen         binnen         de         geesteswetenschappen.         De         volgende         thema’s         komen         aan         de         orde:

1.     Wetenschapsfilosofie (wat is kennis? Wat zijn wetenschappelijke methodes? Wat is verschil tussen verklaren en interpreteren?  Hoe onderscheiden gw zich van natuur- of sociale wetenschappen? Hoe werken zij er mee samen? Wat is de talige wending (linguistic turn) en wat betekent zij voor gw?

2.             Wetenschapsgeschiedenis         (Wanneer         zijn         GW         ontstaan?         Sinds         wanneer         vormen         zij         een         eenheid?         Welke         rol         speelden         sekse,         huisdkleur         en         klasse         in         het         ontstaan         van         de         gw?         Zijn         de         geesteswetenschappen         versplinterd         of         juist         multidisciplinaire         verzamel-studies?         Wat         betekenen         nieuwe         media         en         digitalisering         voor         de         studie         van         taal,         cultuur,         geschiedenis         en         communicatie?)

3.             Wetenschapskritiek         (Wiens         vragen         beantwoorden         de         geesteswetenschappen?          Functioneren         geesteswetenschappers         nationaal,         Europees,         Westers         of         mondiaal?         Welke         economische         waarde         heeft         kennis         van         taal,         cultuur,         geschiedenis?         Wat         kunnen         gw         bijdragen         aan         de         oplossing         van         de         grote         maatschappelijke         problemen         van         onze         tijd?          Waar         ligt         de         grens         tussen         wetenschap         en         politiek,         tussen         wetenschap         en         commercie?         Tussen         wetenschap          en         hobbyisme??)

Studenten bestuderen         wetenschapsfilosofische         teksten         en         volgen         hoorcolleges.         De         wekelijkse         werkcolleges         bestaan         uit         intensieve         peerreviews,         presentaties,         bespreking         van         collegestof         en         discussies         naar         aanleiding         van         actualiteit.         De         cursus         is         schrijf-intensief:         studenten         schrijven         en         herschrijven         beschouwingen         en         stellen         tenslotte         een         dossier         van         ca.         4000         woorden         over         hun         specialisme          samen.

De cursus is         verplicht         voor         TCS         studenten         die         deze         cursus         in         hun         derde         jaar         volgen.         Zij         schrijven         tijdens         deze         cursus         hun         vierde         reflectieopdracht         voor         hun         portfolio.         De         docent         geeft         feedback         op         deze         opdracht         en         tekent         voor         voldaan.         Studenten         van         andere         GW         bachelor         opleidingen         zijn         zeer         welkom.

column3: De student is in staat om:

column5: met behulp van de verworven kennis van de geschiedenis, theorie en methodologie van de (sociale) geografie zelfstandig niet te moeilijk gestelde theoretische, historische en methodologische bijdragen op het terrein van de sociale geografie te lezen, te begrijpen en op hun waarde te schatten.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De cursus begint met een inleiding tot het vak wetenschapsgeschiedenis. Die inleiding vormt de context waarbinnen de ontwikkeling van de internationale en Nederlandse (sociale) geografie wordt onderzocht vanaf circa 1880 tot op heden. De belangrijkste stromingen en opvattingen worden besproken, alsmede hun theoretische concepties en praktische uitwerking. Deze stromingen en opvattingen worden bezien in hun onderlinge samenhang, in relatie tot de maatschappelijke context waarin ze voorkomen (voorkwamen), en in relatie tot de sociale- en omgevingswetenschappen.
Laatste informatie over werkvorm, toets en literatuur is te vinden in de studiewijzer.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176428,2016,Theorie in praktijk: Duitse taal in het onderwijs,Dutch,Graduate School of Teaching,,['dr. B.G. Mariacher'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Aan het einde van deze cursus kun je: – Globale kennis van en inzicht in de verschillende elementaire disciplines binnen de taalkunde (fonetiek en fonologie, morfologie, syntaxis, semantiek, pragmatiek) – met betrekking tot de Duitse taal en waar nodig ook Duits-Nederlands contrastief – aantonen; – Globale kennis van en inzicht in enkele relevante taalverwervings- en taalleertheorieën aantonen; – Gesproken taaluitingen fonetisch analyseren en weergeven met behulp van het fonetisch schrift (IPA); – Geschreven taaluitingen syntaktisch analyseren; – Het grammatica-aanbod (theorie en oefeningen) in een willekeurige lesmethode voor het voortgezet onderwijs in Nederland vanuit didactisch-theoretisch oogpunt analyseren en beschrijven; – Enkele actuele discussies binnen de vreemdetalendidactiek benoemen en hierin een positie innemen; – Verworven kennis en inzicht over taalkunde, taaldidactiek en taalwetenschappelijk onderzoek vertalen naar onderwijs voor leerlingen in de bovenbouw HAVO/VWO;

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit college behandelt fundamentele aspecten van de Duitse taal (uitspraak, woordvorming, zinsbouw), zowel vanuit wetenschappelijk als didactisch oogpunt. Allereerst worden de belangrijkste principes van de fonetiek en fonologie besproken, zodat de toekomstige docent zijn/haar scholieren op een gefundeerde manier in uitspraak van het Duits kan onderwijzen. Daarnaast maken de studenten kennis met belangrijke concepten binnen de morfologie (woordvorming) en de syntaxis (zinsbouw) en leren ze deze concepten te vertalen naar de onderwijspraktijk in het Nederlands voortgezet onderwijs.
Tijdens de colleges wordt er ook enige aandacht besteed aan een contrastieve analyse van het Duits en het Nederlands, met name waar de talen van elkaar verschillen. Aan de hand van deze inzichten kunnen toekomstige docenten o.a. bepalen welke onderwerpen in de klas meer of minder expliciete aandacht behoeven. Ook is er aandacht voor verschillende taalverwervings- en taalleertheorieën en hun neerslag in de onderwijspraktijk (bijv. in lesmethodes), het Europees Referentie Kader, verschillende visies op grammaticaonderwijs en andere actuele discussies over talendidactiek.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/173412,2016,Theories and Concepts of Theatre, Dance and Dramaturgy",English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. M.J. Kattenbelt'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Students gain a thorough theoretical understanding of core theories and concepts and the discourse surrounding these concepts.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Theories and Concepts of Theatre, Dance and Dramaturgy introduces students to a selection of theoretical concepts and approaches useful for the analysis and interpretation of recent trends and topics in the contemporary field of European theatre, dance and performance. Starting point will be the perspective on recent developments in theatre and dance practice provided by Hans-Thies Lehmann's book Postdramatic Theatre in which he observes that the development of Western European theatre of the past decades is characterised by a general move away from drama as a means to structure theatrical performance which has led to, amongst other things, increased interdisciplinarity, new hybrid forms, new approaches to representation, as well as radical changes in spectatorial address. In this course, we will critically discuss a series of theoretical concepts: postdramatic theatre, performance & performativity, theatricality & representation, intermediality, digital culture & posthumanism and corporeal literacy. The course allows students to gain a thorough theoretical understanding of these concepts and the discourse surrounding these concepts. The course trains skills of aptly and critically reading and presenting particular discourses and/or theoretical approaches. In this respect the course relates to Performance Research Lab – Act 1.
This course can be taken, if approved by the course coordinator, as a 7.5 EC course by students started in 2014-2015 or earlier.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174289,2016,Theories and Methods in the Study of Religion,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. P. Tamimi Arab'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In terms of content, it is the intention of this course to introduce students to important debates about the role of religion in modern culture and to new approaches in the study of religion.

With regard to academic skills, the course aims at improving students’ ability to follow and analyze complex scientific discussions and subsequently find their own position therein. Progress will be tested in discussion and based on the quality of an academic paper (as preparation for the MA thesis). Special attention will also be given to presentation skills, which are a crucial part of academic practice</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The aim of this course is twofold. Firstly, through close reading and discussion of seminal contributions to the academic study of religions, students arrive at a better understanding of the specific problems and debates of this discipline. Secondly, it is a platform for students to practice and train their skills of presentation, performance, and discussion. The reading material will have a special focus on contemporary critical theory and new approaches to the study of religion. These approaches will be discussed in relation to the students’ ongoing research.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174462,2016,Theories of Violent Conflict,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J. Demmers'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course will survey and critically examine theoretical approaches to the causes and conditions of contemporary violent conflict. The main purpose of the course is to present and critique various theoretical approaches to conflict; to evaluate the usefulness of these approaches by applying them to specific cases; and to encourage and assist students to develop a multi-disciplinary analytical framework.

•          to improve your ability to distinguish the epistemological and ontological stances underlying approaches of contemporary conflict in, for instance, the media, policy reports and academic research;
•          to increase your ability to recognize, define, deploy, connect, critique and construct abstract knowledge about social life (theory), in particular on violent conflict;
•          to help you to develop your own voice and find your own position in the ongoing conversation on violent conflict among social scientists. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course aims to provide you with an multi-disciplinary and multi-level theoretical vocabulary on how and why (groups of) people resort to violent action against other (groups of) combatants, civilians, organisations or the state. It equips you with the theoretical literacy and analytical capacity to synergize theoretical perspectives in the understanding and explanation of violent conflict. </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174258,2016,Theory and Critical Research I,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. K. Thiele'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completion of this course, the student
A) has gained thorough knowledge of the state of the arts theories and critical research in Gender Studies
B) has been familarised with a cartographic approach to the conceptual 'road map' of feminist, queer, critical race, and postcolonial perspectives
C) will be able to apply theories and concepts to concrete case studies for further analysis
D) will be able to present the acquired knowledge in an academically sufficient manner in both written and oral form.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This core research seminar is designed for Research MA students in Gender (and Postcolonial) Studies. It introduces students to cutting edge research, with specific focus on a cartographic approach to the genre of 'feminist theories' (used here as umbrella term for the fields of feminist, queer, critical race, postcolonial studies perspectives). This course explores the most important strands of feminist theorizing in the last decades up to today. The course opens with a situating of the ideas that helped to shape the project of Gender Studies in Europe such as we know it today. The seminar then investigates into the multiple domains in which race, gender, sexuality, ethnicity, class and ability shape our daily experience and how they can be accounted for in research work. Central topics to be explored are: deconstruction of binary oppositions structuring (Western) thought; deconstructiong of eurocentrism; the debate of essentialism vs. (social) constructionism; decolonial knowledges in feminist research; trans*, queer, and posthuman(ist) challenges to the sex/gender matrix in Gender Studies.

This course trains the students in foundational knowledge in the field of Gender Studies and emphasizes their socio-political embedding and relevance. It thereby teaches the students in foundational manners to contribute to a societally relevant understanding of higher education in the humanities.

Students who are required to return to their home university by the end of December, are allowed to complete the course by 'distance learning' (extra assignments, papers etc) in the month of January, receiving 5 ECTS for the course. Students must always make individual arrangements with the course coordinator before the start of the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course, the student:
A) has acquired specialized knowledge of state-of-the-art theory and critical research in feminist, queer, critical race, and/or postcolonial studies
B) has developed a historical and theoretical understanding of significant shifts in the field of cultural analysis
C) can close-read theoretical texts and then apply concepts to concrete case studies
D) has gained confidence in presenting academic findings in both written and oral form

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Following up on Theory and Critical Research I, this core research seminar delves more deeply into cutting-edge theory and critical research in feminist, queer, critical race, and/or postcolonial studies. While the topics covered in this seminar will change each year according to the instructor's area of expertise, the course will consistently pose questions that are of particular relevance to feminists and others concerned with social justice at this historical moment. The course will take as its point of departure an intersectional approach to gender, sexuality, race, nation, class, and ability, as well as to relations between subject matter, discipline, time, place, and theory. This research seminar will also trace the development of historical and theoretical understandings in the field of cultural analysis, examining the ways in which texts and images perform cultural hierarchies. The presented theoretical and conceptual frameworks will be illustrated by close readings and textual analyses. In addressing theory and critical research as an ongoing, future-oriented cultural endeavor, this course grapples with academic and ethical questions that are relevant to current politics with transnational relevance.

This course trains the students in foundational knowledge in the field of Gender Studies and emphasizes their socio-political embedding and relevance. It thereby teaches the students in foundational manners to contribute to a societally relevant understanding of higher education in the humanities.     </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing the course, students are able to:

column5: Understand key topics in the field of Africa Studies
Summarize key debates in international development and aid.
Develop a sophisticated analysis of the primary challenges facing the continent, situating them according to historical legacies and current political economy
Develop skills and competencies pertaining to critical analysis, lateral thinking, and self-reflexivity
Analyse, critique chosen topics for specialization and engagement in students’ specific internship sites.
Strengthen their oral and written communication skills, including the development and public defence of a project proposal.
Orient students to the context of the field course (Tanzania & Kenya) as well as internship locations
In order to pass these course students must demonstrate the ability to apply
Writing and analytical skills.
Presentation skills.
Team working skills.
Multicultural skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This is a mandatory course for students participating in UCINTDEV31. It is specially designed to prepare students for the issues and challenges confronted during the field course in Tanzania and Kenya, including their internships in the East Africa region. The course has a two-fold focus. First, it aims to provide students with a theoretical foundation in African Studies, including history, postcolonial theory, international political economy, and change in modern Africa. Concomitantly, the course offers a review of development theory, including deliberation on key contemporary challenges facing the African continent, and current approaches to redress them. The course takes a regional case study approach on development issues in Africa, with a focus especially on East Africa.

The course is designed in seminar format, with an emphasis on student participation and class discussion. It represents a rather intensive reading course wherein students are expected to effectively engage in the designated class themes. The course will include various media review, lectures, and guest talks; nevertheless, it will emphasize student-led discussion and presentations. One of the primary foci in the course is to provide a platform for students to identify, explore and articulate their selected internship topics. Accordingly, students are expected to identify, present and debate their topic via project proposals and corresponding presentations.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/171045,2016,Theory construction and statistical modeling,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. L.D.N.V. Wijngaards', 'M.N. Houtveen, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Learning to translate social scientific theories into models. Learning to analyse models using SPSS and AMOS.

The test(s) consist(s) of different parts. To test whether the student learned how to translate social scientific theories in models the student will be given one or multiple research questions for which the student has to choose the correct way of analysis and has to perform the appropriate analysis accordingly. To test whether the student learned how to analyse models the student is expected to make correct interpretations of the output from AMOS and/or SPSS that the student is presented with. To test the general knowledge of the student about statistical modeling in the final part of the test there will be statements of which the student has to indicate whether they are true or false.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Note: This course can also be taken as part of the honours programme (and then includes additional work and guidance). Contact the course coordinator if you are an honours student.

Note: Students that cannot comply with the entrance requirements mentioned below will be asked to provide further information on their eligibility. The course coordinator will decide on their eligibility.
Assumed knowledge: Anova and regression analysis. Participants should be familiar with SPSS.

In the social sciences statistics are used to test whether a theory can be rejected or not. SPSS is used as a statistical toolkit to do this. SPSS however cannot be used to test many of the theories that are used in psychology, sociology, pedagogical sciences and educational sciences. In this course, you will be introduced to Structural Equation Modeling, a flexible, intuitive technique that will enable you to test almost all possible theories directly using empirical data.

Based upon data that is provided at the introduction of the course, you will cycle through all phases of social scientific research. More specifically you will learn to translate a social scientific theory into a statistical model. You will learn to analyse your data with these models. And finally you will learn to interpret and report your results. Analyses will be executed using the statistical modeling packages SPSS and AMOS. SPSS is a combination of a data-editing and data analysis program. It is possible to build statistical models in SPSS, but for some questions building these models is either cumbersome or impossible. For this we use the computer program AMOS. AMOS analyses data based upon a graphical representation of the model the user is interested in, it is a so-called 'user-friendly' program. In the graph the user can specify regression type models and factor analytic models.

column3: In this course the emphasis is on the methodological aspects of measurement and the testing of theories. We will discuss among others the following topics: 1) How can I test whether questions measure what they intend to measure?, 2) How to test complicated models (mediation and path models), 3) Whether statistical models differ for sub-groups in your population.</body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174130,2016,Theory for technology,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. R. Duine', 'prof. dr. P.P.A.M. van der Schoot']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Introduce and sensitise students of theoretical physics at UU to current research topics relevant to experimental and/or applied physics in direct collaboration with research groups at Eindhoven University of Technology TU/e. Research at the department of Applied Physics of TU/e focuses on three main research programmes: functional materials, plasma physics and radiation technology, and transport physics. These main programmes encompass topics such as fusion technology, materials processing, gas discharges, turbulence, nanofluidics, flow in disordered media, photo-voltaics, organic field-effect transistors, quantum information, liquid crystals, molecular-controlled release vehicles, biosensors and many others. For details, refer to the website of Applied Physics at TU/e, https://www.tue.nl/en/university/departments/applied-physics/.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course is not a regular class but a research project or a literature study on a specific topic relevant to applied and experimental physics, and technology. The student is expected to consult the website of the Department of Applied Physics at TU/e, https://www.tue.nl/en/university/departments/applied-physics/, and find a research group working on a class of physics problems that interests the student. The contact at ITF (Prof. Paul van der Schoot) introduces the student to the relevant staff member at TU/e. That TU/e staff member and the student agree upon a theoretical project or literature study that is of interest to the experimental research group at TU/e and the student. If necessary, an expert co-supervisor at the ITF will be found. The project/literature study may be performed at UU or TU/e, depending on the wishes of the student.
The course may prepare the student for the master's thesis project, that is, the student could take the it as an early introduction into the final year's thesis work.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het eind van deze cursus is de student in staat om:

column2: • de anatomie van het perifere zenuwstelsel te beschrijven;
• de invloed van het autonome zenuwstelsel op hartactiviteit en vaattonus te beschrijven;
• De anatomie, contractie en aansturing van contractie van skeletspieren, gladde spieren en de hartspier te beschrijven;
• de werking van de nier te beschrijven;
• de anatomie van het cardiovasculaire stelsel te beschrijven;
• de pathogenese en risico’s van verhoogde bloeddruk te beschrijven;
• de werkingsmechanismen van de belangrijkste antihypertensiva te beschrijven;
• de voornaamste bijwerkingen van de antihypertensiva te noemen en verklaren;
• enkele klinisch-chemische bepalingen uit te voeren en de meetwaarden te relateren aan farmacotherapeutische interventies;
• uit te leggen hoe de effectiviteit en de incidentie van bijwerkingen van antihypertensiva gemeten worden;
• de belangrijkste redenen waarom patiënten afwijkend reageren op een geneesmiddel te noemen en verklaren (zoals farmacogenetica, therapietrouw etc);
• uit te leggen welke factoren een rol spelen bij het kiezen voor een behandeling voor een patiënt (beleid, richtlijnen, evidence, individuele patiëntfactoren, klinisch-chemische parameters etc.).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus staat de medicamenteuze behandeling van een patiënt met verhoogde bloeddruk, arteriële hypertensie, centraal. Een belangrijk leerdoel is dat de student gewenste en ongewenste effecten van geneesmiddelen kan verklaren aan de hand van de farmacologische eigenschappen van die middelen en (patho)fysiologische processen in het lichaam.

Om de aandoening en vooral de werking van de verschillende antihypertensiva goed te kunnen begrijpen is kennis nodig van de circulatie (hart, vaten), de nier (o.a. nierdoorbloeding, GFR, Na+‐ en K+ secretie,  countercurrentprincipe) en de bloeddrukregulatiemechanismen (RAAS, baroreceptormechanisme). In dit kader komen ook de skeletspieren en het autonome zenuwstelsel langs en de verschillende manieren waarop de functie daarvan kan worden beïnvloed. De student maakt kennis met klinisch‐chemische bepalingsmethoden als hulpmiddel bij diagnostiek en therapie. Ook vindt een kennismaking plaats met clinical evidence en richtlijnen.

column4: Plaats van het blok in het curriculum:
Jaar 3, 1e deel van 2e semester (= periode 3). De student kan kiezen gedurende de
gehele derde periode (10 weken) aan de thesis te werken. Een andere mogelijkheid
is om de thesis binnen 5 weken te schrijven (gedurende de eerste of tweede helft
Korte omschrijving van het blok en uitgangspunten:
In dit blok moet de student een individueel bachelorwerkstuk produceren. De
belangrijkste leerdoelen zijn: (1) een project zelfstandig leren uitvoeren met volledige
eigen verantwoordelijkheid; (2) verbeteren van de schrijfvaardigheid en leren
zorgvuldig formuleren; (3) oriëntatie op één van de veterinaire beroepsvelden; (4)
kritisch verwerken van nieuwe informatie uit verschillende bronnen; (5)
voorbereiding op de onderzoekstage (facultatief). Voor een overzicht van de
leerdoelen wordt verwezen naar de ‘Eindtermen Curriculum Diergeneeskunde’1. Het
onderwerp van het werkstuk dient veterinair of biomedisch van aard te zijn.

body { font-size: 9pt; writing scripts to collect, manage and analyze text.

column3: The aim of the thesis is to independently write a report of research conducted under supervision of a senior researcher. The thesis shows how the knowledge and skills acquired during the RMA programme has equipped the students with the research, academic and communicative skills to carry out original research.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A substantial component involves writing scripts (simple programs) in the Python programming language.  We will learn how to use scripts to manage and analyze texts (“corpus analysis”), carry out searches that go far beyond what you can do with a standard web form, count words and constructions, create randomized experimental stimuli, etc.
Students will become familiar with different types of digital language resources, and some of their uses in theoretical or experimental research.
The skills learned in this course can be applied to employment outside academia, in the domain of natural language processing. The programming component has even broader utility.

Together with the internship, the thesis constitutes the individual trajectory of the student. During the internship, the focus is on research questions defined by the project the student is participating in. For the thesis, emphasis is placed on original research driven by the student's own questions. The exact activities/tasks, mode of working, schedule and expected outcomes may vary across thesis research projects, but they are all always agreed upon at the beginning of the thesis project. Students are responsible for finding their own supervisor. In all cases student must have an internal supervisor affiliated with UiL OTS. A student may have an additional internal or external supervisor. An external supervisor is a senior researcher affiliated with an institution other than UiL OTS. The responsibility for the final grade and its entering in Osiris lies always on the internal supervisor. The output of the thesis research is a report that meets the standards of a scientific publication in the subdiscipline of linguistics at hand. The thesis should be structured around a central research question to which it provides an answer. The central research question should be clearly formulated at the beginning and its relevance to scholarly discussions within the discipline set out. The body of the text should show how the question was answered, why the approach chosen is adequate, and what the final outcomes are. The conclusion should contain an analysis of the findings in the light of the original question, and explain the broader implications of the research carried out. There are no strict guidelines as to length, but most theses are between 40 and 70 pages long (including notes, bibliography and appendices).Most students write the thesis in the second semester of the se cond year. A thesis seminar is run in that semester for group and individual support.
Orientation on a future research oriented career in academia or outside of academia</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This a required course and is open to U.S.E. Master students only.

For their master thesis, students conduct independent research towards answering the research question they have formulated in the preceeding research project. The writing of the thesis can be combined with an internship although that will not yield additional credits. The thesis must be written individually.

The thesis is the final part of the master’s programme. It must reflect many of the learning objectives of the programme’s various courses. In particular, after successful completion of the thesis, students have shown that they are able to:

column2: • Apply modern economic theories, possibly in combination with other academic fields
• Demonstrate an academic attitude towards solving complex economic problems
• Select the relevant research method: theoretical, empirical, experimental, or any combination
• Assess the contribution of own research within the realm of the existing body of knowledge
• Write an advanced research report in English

column1: Each student has been assigned a supervisor in the preceding research project and has developed a research question. During a two-period time frame the student will have regular bilateral meetings with their supervisor. The contents and frequency of these meetings is to be decided by the thesis advisor, in consultation with the student. A second supervisor is involved in the process as well with the following tasks: (i) to approve the research question and set up of the thesis before the student starts working on the thesis, and (ii) to read the final manuscript as approved by the first supervisor, and to determine the thesis grade in consultation with the first supervisor.

column3: The final project tests the student’s exit level in the field of Intercultural Communication. The student shows s/he is able to conduct research on an aspect of ICC and to place his/her work within the context of earlier research and the public debate. The final product is a report of the student’s research that has to meet academic standards. The report must be detailed, verifiable and systematic. The student shows s/he is able to present results effectively. Futher details regarding form and content of the final project can be found in the ICC program book and on the web site for the MA programme in ICC: Interculturele communicatie  >studieprogramma >afstudeerproject.

Course load, duration, supervision, procedure and assessment are described in the Richtlijnen Masterthesis, which can be downloaded from the web site for the MA programme in ICC: Interculturele communicatie >studieprogramma >afstudeerproject.

Students wanting qualify for the English stream should register for the English programme in ICC.Their final papers should be written in English and at least one of their supervisors should be in the English Department, monitoring the language specific requirements.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Verwerven van praktische ervaring in het opzetten, uitvoeren, rapporteren en beoordelen van ontwikkelingspsychologisch onderzoek.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The subject of the master’s thesis has to be within the domain of developmental psychology. Furthermore, it has to add to the empirical body of knowledge of developmental psychology, and/or improve the quality of functioning of developmental psychologists working in the field. The hypotheses need to be supported by a theoretical framework. Students can participate in one of the current projects in the department. These projects focus on themes in the fields of normal as well as problematic development of children and adolescents in different social contexts (home, school, peer group). These projects may contain specific research questions that can be used as a basis for the thesis. Every project has a maximum number of participating students. Data collection might be done in couples, but the report is an individual project. Research for the thesis may also be conducted outside of the university, in which case the supervisor will be from the organization where the research is performed, and a member of departmental staff will function as a second supervisor.

To discuss thesis topic and procedures, students should contact the co-ordinator of the programme. It is a prerequisite that a supervisor from the department and the departmental co-ordinator approve the topic the student wishes to study.

After completion of the thesis, the student is able to independently conduct simple psychological research. In addition, the student will have acquired basic skills to write a scientific report in a format that is commonly used in the field.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/170862,2016,Master's thesis clinical and health psychology,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['Docenten van de afdeling/departement(en)'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Het doel van de thesis is te leren zelfstandig te functioneren als onderzoeker. De student moet er blijk van geven een onderwerp uit de wetenschappelijke literatuur op een theoretisch en methodologisch verantwoorde wijze uit te kunnen diepen, een empirisch onderzoek hiernaar uit te voeren en de bevindingen van dit onderzoek zodanig schriftelijk weer te geven dat ze voor anderen toegankelijk zijn. Bij voorkeur doet de student onderzoekservaring op in alle fasen van de empirische cyclus.

Bij het eindoordeel omtrent de masterthesis worden zowel het onderzoeksproces, de schriftelijke verslaglegging en de mondelinge presentatie in ogenschouw genomen, waarmee het geheel van academische, onderzoeks- en, communicatie vaardigheden wordt beoordeeld.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The subject of the master’s thesis has to be within the domain of clinical and health psychology, and has to be linked to the more specific field of one of the supervisors. Main research topics of clinical and health psychology at Utrecht University are: trauma and loss, experimental psychopathology, self-regulation of health and illness, culture and mental health, coping with chronic diseases. Possibilities for working on a research question that is not related to work of a supervisor are limited. This is only possible after the student has handed in an extensive research proposal that is approved by the co-ordinator well in advance. Furthermore, a supervisor has to be available for the project.

To discuss thesis topic and procedures, students should contact the co-ordinator of the programme. It is a prerequisite that a supervisor from the department as well as the departmental co-ordinator approve the topic the student wishes to study.

After completion of the thesis, the student is able to independently conduct uncomplicated psychological research. In addition, the student will have acquired basic skills to write a scientific report in a format that is commonly used in the field.
