column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: 1. to translate a Life Sciences problem into a relevant research question;
2. to select the relevant scientific domains;
4. to critically read scientific papers, and recognize good papers;
5. to discuss papers and argue their strong and weak points;
6. to summarize literature in his/her own words;
7. to discuss the outcomes of his/her own literature survey and link these with scientific theories;
8. to formulate suggestions for (hypotheses) for future research;
9. to write a review article under limited supervision in a limited amount of time (5 weeks);

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The format of a writing assignment can be that if a review paper in the relevant research field (literature review) or a NWO/ALW grant application (a research proposal).

To write a review a significant amount of recent literature is used to create an in-depth discussion, in which the student demonstrates his/her ability to critically evaluate hypotheses and results, presents his/her own views, and draws conclusions that point towards new research opportunities. The assignment should be written in English and contain a summary specifically aimed at informing the general audience about the content (laymen’s summary). A writing assignment consists of several key stages: defining your topic, formulating a hypothesis, drawing up a timetable, literature research and the writing phase. The work is presented orally to the research group.
Prior approval of the Board of examiners is mandatory

column3: On completing the course, students will have developed improved skills in writing in English an empirical-based article for a peer reviewed scientific journal.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Academics spend a great deal of time writing publications in peer reviewed scientific journals. This course focuses on English academic writing and the scientific criteria for the assessment of publications. The seminars on English academic writing will help students to bring their linguistic skills up to standard and improve their ability in argumentation. The students also learn how to identify an innovative topic for a publication, how to structure an article and to address key problems in the process of writing the various sections of scientific publications. Besides, students get familiar with criteria for reviewing papers submitted to journals and learn to apply these criteria on the papers written in this course. The student makes the choice for a topic and journal after consultation of the lecturer. In seminars the students discuss each other’s products. The lecturer gives feedback on the discussion and papers written by the students.
Latest information about the course contents can be found in the course manual.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this online course, which is specifically aimed at professionals, you will enhance your skills in writing a research proposal in English, both in terms of information elements and language. We will analyze the structure, vocabulary and grammatical structures of research proposals, including word order, articles, verb tenses, punctuation marks, modal verbs, hedging, referencing styles, and the use of transitional words and phrases. We will also address the concept of plagiarism and how to avoid it.
Mandatory for students in own Master’s programme:

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174444,2016,Youth and Media,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. D.A. de Vries, PhD', 'dr. H. Vossen', 'M.R. Graauw']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Media play a central role in the lives of youth. Recent reports show that children between 4-7 years of age spent on average 2,5 hours a day with media. Adolescents, with their prolific social media use, spent even more than 8 hours a day with media. In this course we will investigate how children develop as media consumers and how their cognitive, emotional and social development influences media use and media preferences. We will also examine the influence of media use on behavior. Questions such as “Do children become aggressive when they play violent videogames?”, “How does internet-porno influence adolescents views of sex?”, “Can children really learn from educational television and apps?” will be discussed. Finally, we will look at media in a broader context. We will investigate how parents and peers can influence media effects and preferences, and study cultural difference in media use and effects.
It is assumed that participants of this third year Ba course possess the following academic skills:
- knowledge of quantitative and qualitative research designs (including basic statistical methods)
- ability to critically reflect on empirical research
- ability to find academic literature using search engines like Web of Science, PsycINFO or Google Scolar.
- ability to write an academic paper in accordance to the APA (American Psychological Association) rules of style in either English or Dutch
Introduction in psychology or pedagogical science is preferred but not mandatory. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After successful completion of this course, you will have gained knowledge about and insights in:
• How the cognitive, emotional, and social development of children and adolescents predicts their media use and preferences.
• The most important views, theories, and empirical findings in the field of youth and media.
• The positive and negative influences of media use on the behavior of children and adolescents.
• The role of the social and cultural context of children in media effects and preferences.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174456,2016,Youth, Education and Society 01: Paradigms & Practices",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. S.M.A. Sieckelinck', 'MSc M.C. Kesselring', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
The course works towards the following course aims:
The Paradigms & Practices course offers theoretical perspectives and strategies for studying the field of youth, education and societal issues. The course works towards the following course aims:
• To be able to define and have an overview of the field of the master YES; Youth, Education and Society, and be aware of the pertinent issues in this field;
• To know which present-day and historic scientific, theoretical and empirical paradigms are relevant when studying in this field;
• To be able to describe scientific theories concerning and insights into social behaviour, the relationship between behaviour and educational infrastructure, and educational policy development;
• To formulate critical questions and communicate research findings to fellow students and a wider audience;
• To know what is going on in society in terms of education-related issues and be able to contribute to the public debate;

• To write clearly and concisely in a scientific manner, according to the APA guidelines. The APA guidelines (Edition 6) are compulsory for all written papers during the Master's degree. It is important to purchase a copy of the APA manual and apply it carefully;

Apart from the usual objective of imparting knowledge and teaching relevant skills, the lecturers also seek to stimulate scientific curiosity in and commitment to the social issues encountered in the field. This will be done in part through assignments and activities during the lectures, but students are also expected to take the initiative themselves.

The two assignments, i.e. the group assignment and the individual assignment are both in line with the (learning) goals for this course.  Whilst students will be individually assessed on their understanding and knowledge of the theory (through a literature-based advice for follow-up research on their Bachelor Thesis), they will undergo group assessment regarding skills and their ability to reflect on their (cooperation) skills (through designing, developing, and engaging in a small scale naturalistic inquiry) needed in the field of Youth, Education, and Society.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: The first course in the Master's degree programme discusses the main perspectives and strategies that are useful for studying Youth, Education and Society. The course offers theoretical perspectives and practical strategies for studying educational issues in society and learning to conduct analyses within the triangle of scientific research, policies and professional practice. Developing a theoretical approach and working with different perspectives and ideas in practice are extremely important within the programme. Students are assessed on a group field assignment (40%) and an individual literature assignment (60%).

The course consists of six (theory-practice) lectures given by two lecturers, in which theory is introduced and discussed and feedback is provided on the assignment. In the seminars, the lecturers discuss the required reading and relate the Community Psychology, Educational Civil Society, Critical and Normative Pedagogy, Naturalistic Inquiry and Social Governance literature to the Dutch situation and the study of Youth, Education and Society on the international stage. Each lecture focuses on the assigned reading for that week. Any additional literature (articles) will be published on Blackboard.

In the second part of each lecture, students meet in two different types of group: field assignment groups and literature assignment peer support groups. The group field assignment is designed around an educational problem in society, which municipality X or organisation Y is trying to address and aims to teach students to contribute to innovative solutions. A key trait of this teaching format is that learning largely takes place through interaction with the actors in whom and situations in which the problem manifests itself. In small groups, students then analyse a real educational issue currently playing out in a Dutch municipality or organisation. The analysis involves considering scientific literature, policy analysis, interviews, observations and evaluating the current ideas of how to tackle the issue.

The individual literature assignment is to provide a commentary – informed by the literature – on the student's own Bachelor’s thesis, based on the question: What further research would you recommend now that you have a greater understanding of the paradigms considered on this course? Each student then details whether and how these theories offer a different perspective on the actual study and on the proposed follow-up research.

Feedback sessions will be scheduled in the last period, at which the lecturer will be present, but the students will mainly work together on the assignment. The group assignment is concluded with a final presentation. The quality of the presentation counts towards the mark for the group field assignment.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174455,2016,Youth, Education and Society 02: Global Perspectives and Cultural Diversity",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. C.F. Garandeau, PhD', 'prof. dr. M. de Winter', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan', 'prof. dr. P.P.M. Leseman', 'R van Esch, MSc']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
1) to acquire knowledge and understanding of global perspectives & cultural diversity in the area of childhood, youth, and education;
2) to acquire knowledge and understanding of the international policy context, including international development, concerning children and young people, upbringing and education;
3) to acquire an understanding of how knowledge of youth, education and society can be translated into a variety of different social, economic and cultural contexts;
4) to gain skills to apply the course knowledge into individual scientific writing;
5) to gain skills to apply the course knowledge into a practical knowledge related to interventions and policy in a collaborative context.

In the individual paper students will be examined with respect to their knowledge and understanding of the theoretical knowledge that is required in the course (course goals 1 to 3) as well as how they are able to put these insights into scientific writing (course goal 4). In the group assignments students will be examined with respect to how they are able to apply the scientific knowledge of the course (goal 1 to 3) into a practice based assignment in a collaborative context (course goal 5).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: The focus of the course is the question how the development of youth and children can be optimized when working cross-culturally from a scientific, professional and policy perspective.

Within this general theme, we address themes as health, care and education and work as interrelated but separate subthemes. We study programmatic and policy attempts to improve the living circumstances and educational environments of youth, and analyse the scientific bases that underlies these. International development takes a central position in the course, next to other situations in which cultural knowledge is transferred cross-culturally, such as in situations of migration. Special target groups, such as child soldiers, street children, children with disabilities or children affected by AIDS will be addressed, while also paying attention to the situation of immigrant children and youth in welfare countries.

A key theme in the course is cultural diversity and the understanding of cultural diversity in the context of knowledge transfer between communities that are geographically or culturally far apart. How can we transfer knowledge that was constituted and formed in a Western setting and make it work in a non-Western setting? What should be the position of that (Western) knowledge in an increasingly culturally diverse world? How can this knowledge transfer be understood from the perspective of globalization, especially given the contact with other regions in the world? In this course you learn to think and act as a scientist and a professional when dealing with or working with scientific knowledge, intervention programs and policies, in (inter)national contexts that are culturally diverse.

You will examine Western ideas on international development, as well as the need to reshape these ideas. You will consider how local differences between the lives of young people in the Western world and the non-Western world, for example, determine their opportunities, developmental prospects and limitations. In this process, you will learn how to think from multiple perspectives. For example, more instrumental and technological approaches are contrasted with more critical views on international collaboration.

On this course, you will learn to take position in guided discussion groups, and write a position paper.  Furthermore, you will gain practical experience with applying scientific knowledge in designing an intervention in an intercultural setting. Students may choose to do this either in an international development setting or in a migration setting.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174457,2016,Youth, Education and Society 03: Prevention 3.0: Perspectives & Design",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. E. van de Weijer-Bergsma', 'dr. W.M. van Londen-Barentsen', 'J.J. Endendijk, PhD', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
• about the perspective of Prevention Science including scientific theories and evidence-based preventive interventions (prevention 1.0)

• about the perspective of the Dutch Youth Act's (Jeugdwet) and Appropriate Education Law (Passend Onderwijs wet; inclusive education) on prevention and the implementation of these perspectives (e.g. de-medicalization, normalization, community perspective) into local contexts or instead gain knowledge about youth legislation and preventive principles in another country;

• to cooperate with other students in designing an innovative intervention based on scientific  knowledge for a specific local context. In this creative group challenge to design a preventive intervention (prevention 3.0) students need to achieve a balance between relevant scientific theories and empirical knowledge on evidence based interventions (prevention 1.0 perspective) on the one hand and the prevention 2.0 (legislative) principles on upbringing and educational issues and the vision and needs of professional stakeholders and end-users in the local context on the other hand. The prevention 3.0 design for an preventive intervention can also be constructed for an international context.

Starting the course with the group assignment, students learn to cooperate and choose a local context and issue to write the group assignment. The scientific  literature and the lectures on prevention in the family, school, early child care and community context provide insights to incorporate in the assignment. By giving and receiving peer feedback and feedback by the teacher according to standardized rubrics students learn to apply both perspectives on several issues. With the individual take home (open-book) assignment students are asked during a 4-hour assignment to show their acquired knowledge and skills in analysing a given local case by prevention 1.0 as well as by prevention 2.0 perspectives and to propose a balanced prevention design based on both perspectives (prevention 3.0). During the closing session students are challenged to present their design via a pitch as well as a group presentation to pursue ‘’a virtual grant’’ in a group contest.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In this course, you will learn to contribute to and design innovative preventive interventions taking the legislative context of the new Youth Act (2015) in the Netherlands as a starting point, as well as how to combine different perspectives on prevention. Within the Youth Act municipalities in the Netherlands are responsible  for health and welfare of children and adolescents. This transition (decentralisation, shifting financial resources and the administrative framework from the central government, provincial governments and healthcare insurance companies to local authorities) is taking place hand-in-hand with a transformation: a new approach to supporting, helping and caring for young people and families based on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC, 1990). A similar transition took place within the educational system. Since 2014 schools in the Netherlands have a duty of care, to offer all pupils an appropriate place. This is called Appropriate (inclusive) Education, which shows strong links with the new Youth Act and forces local youth care teams to cooperate with care teams within schools.

Two major starting points of these new policies are 1) prevention and 2) de-medicalization and normalization. Instead of the former used at-risk vision in youth care, municipalities are challenged to stimulate and provide more preventive interventions in and near the local contexts of children and their caregivers (in the community and at schools) en empower their caregivers in strengthening their own resources and community.   Both changes in policy require professionals who can work on developing  pedagogical infrastructures in line with these goals, and who can develop and evaluate appropriate new preventive interventions based on scientific state-of-the-art knowledge.

This course deals with the question of how educational, community and psychological perspectives on prevention, and empirical knowledge on effective interventions can be integrated into this new legal framework. To that end, we will examine a range of perspectives on prevention. Taking the Dutch situation as a starting point, students will also learn to apply these approaches to social youth policies or perspectives on prevention prevalent in other countries.

Prevention 1.0: focuses on (developments in) scientific perspectives and empirical knowledge of prevention strategies. The fundaments of this perspective are based on classic ‘prevention science’ – an academic field with its own conceptual framework and empirical knowledge base. We will also consider evidence-based preventive interventions.

Prevention 2.0: The Dutch Youth Act primarily concentrates on prevention, de-medicalization and normalization, emphasizing the 'strength within the individual', 'strengthening the educative civil society' (De Winter, 2012), and the importance of 'regular upbringing and education'. A significant addition here is collaboration between volunteers and professionals.  In other European countries similar developments are seen based on the UNCRC- convention, challenging professionals to adjust interventions to local contexts.

Prevention 3.0: The challenge nowadays  for this transformation as put forward in the Youth Act and Appropriate Education is to link both perspectives (1.0 and 2.0) to each other and to design, develop and evaluate preventive interventions, supported by the  empirical knowledge gained in Prevention 1.0, within the societal context of the Youth Act and the basic principles examined in Prevention 2.0.  Students will design  a preventive intervention based on the perspectives of Prevention 1.0 and Prevention 2.0, and integrate this knowledge and these skills into a vision and combined design for Prevention 3.0, within the new local context, based on needs-assessments of stakeholders.

During the course, you will attend a series of lectures and guest lectures, read and search for scientific literature and policy memoranda, and work together with other students on designing an innovative intervention in a local context.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174458,2016,Youth, Education and Society 04: Digital Media and Youth",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['dr. D.A. de Vries, PhD', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.

1. Students are aware of, understand, and can critically evaluate different debates and different (pessimistic and optimistic) views within these debates about the implications of digital media for youth’s lives, their development, their relationships with others (e.g., peers, parents, and educators) and their role in society, both in national and international contexts.
2. Students have knowledge of and can apply scientific theories relevant for the domain of youth and (digital) media.

3. Students can formulate relevant research questions about the implications digital media have for youth’s lives and can critically evaluate and apply different research methods to answer these questions.

4. Students are able to understand the social policy implications of the different views on digital media and youth and can form realistic conclusions and recommendations about the possibilities and risks of digital media for youth’s lives.

5. Students can convey recommendations to policymakers, parents, educators, and young people in a clear and attractive manner, and can translate these recommendations into national and international regulations, policies, and interventions.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: New technologies often trigger mixed reactions. Proponents revel in the new possibilities the technologies, such as digital media, offer for young people’s lives, their education and development, their relationships with others (e.g., peers, parents, and educators), and their role in society. At the same time, opponents warn against the risks and detrimental effects of the new technology. This course focuses on the implications of new technologies for youth, education, and society. You will deal with questions such as: “What impact does technology have on the quality of friendships, privacy, and the identity of youth?” “How can we use technology to benefit learning?” “How does technology change relationships with parents?” You will also learn to provide recommendations about what educators, policymakers, and young people themselves can do to prevent negative effects and promote positive effects of new technologies and design policies or programs directed at youth that take new technologies into account.

When you have completed this course you will be aware of and understand the current debates about technology and youth, education, and society. You will be able to critically evaluate pessimistic and optimistic views within these debates, place them in a broader national and international context, and form your own realistic conclusions about the possibilities and risks of these technologies. In this course you will learn how to evaluate these views based on the research of others as well as on your own research. The course will enable you to develop a keen eye for identifying questions about youth and digital media that are raised by different groups in our (national and international) society. You will learn to translate research outcomes into recommendations as well as into regulations, policies, and interventions. In addition, you will learn to communicate your conclusions and recommendations to different target groups in an attractive and effective way.

The literature selected for this course will provide you with the (theoretical) knowledge you need to understand and to contribute to current and future debates about youth and digital media. The seminars are designed to deepen your understanding of this literature, to apply this knowledge to different (international) contexts and to develop your own views. During the lectures you will learn about different ways to conduct research about digital media and youth, education, and society from researchers themselves. In addition, you will be working on a group assignment in which you will carry out your own research on digital platforms on which youth are active. In this group assignment you will apply your knowledge, understanding, and views of digital media and youth, education, and society and of research in one particular area. You will also practice with effectively communicating your findings and recommendations to different target groups.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174513,2016,Youth, Education and Society 05: Academic Professional",English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,"['A Nieuwboer', 'Dielwart, MSc', 'dr. A. Ünlüsoy', 'dr. C. Baerveldt', 'dr. C.F. Garandeau, PhD', 'dr. D.A. de Vries, PhD', 'dr. E. van de Weijer-Bergsma', 'dr. E.H. Kroesbergen', 'dr. H. Vossen', 'dr. O. Oudgenoeg-Paz', 'dr. P.L. Slot', 'dr. P.L.M. Baar', 'dr. S.M.A. Sieckelinck', 'dr. W.M. van Londen-Barentsen', 'drs. B. Horjus', 'J.J. Endendijk, PhD', 'MSc M.C. Kesselring', 'prof. dr. I. Weijers', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan', ""R.A. van 't Rood""]",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
2.1 After following the course, the student will be able to recognize ethical dilemma’s in the discipline of Youth, Education and Society.

2.2 After following the course, the student will be able to reflect critically in ethical terms on his/her own discipline in general and more specific, on his/her own professional and scientific actions in the field.
2.3 After following the course, the student will be able to understand and to reflect on the development of his/her own professional identity and competencies (lifelong learning).

2.4 After following the course, the student will develop an active attitude towards the opportunities the job market provides him/her and will be able to draw implications and consequences for his/her own competencies.
2.5 The student has some experience in job application (orally and in writing) and presents him/herself on LinkedIn as starting academic professional.

2.6 After following the course, the student will have sufficient basic knowledge of legal procedures in relation to Juveniles and Law in order to meet the NVO's entry requirements after completing the Master’s programme.
At the end of the course, students will be asked to write a reflection dossier (80% of the total grade; goal 2.1 till goal 2.5).
A specific part of this course is a series of lectures related to Juveniles and Law, which will be examined by an assignment (20% of the total grade; goal 2.6).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: The Academic Professional year-long linking course integrates the various course components in the Youth, Education, and Society Master’s curriculum. The underlying aim of this is to shape students into academic professionals – critical thinkers who can move smoothly between theory and practice and apply the latest knowledge and basic skills to identify, evaluate and resolve problems in social contexts. The professional field is actively involved in shaping this programme. Students can apply the knowledge, attitudes and skills they learn through various types of learning activities in assignments relating to the professional field of their choice.

Ethics and job market orientation are essential aspects of the Academic Professional course. Ethics (1.5 EC, 42 hours) covers both academic and professional integrity and focuses on critically examining professionals' ethical behaviour in research and educational practices; critically assessing and discussing academic sources; developing academic curiosity; collaborating with stakeholders and taking account of their interests; sharing knowledge; maintaining professional networks; taking part in peer reviews; dealing with conflicting interests of organisations; exhibiting academic integrity as laid down in the Association of Universities in the Netherlands (VSNU)'s Netherlands Code of Conduct for Scientific Practice 2012; gaining an understanding of and being able to reflect on the development of your own professional identity; and being able to realise this by developing your own competencies as relevant to the needs of the job market.

Job market orientation (1.5 EC, 42 hours) concentrates primarily on your professional identity, forming a view on who you are as a professional and being able to articulate this, orally or in writing, and taking your first active steps onto the job market. Students also explore the Association of Educationalists in the Netherlands [NVO] basic educationalist professional profile, as well as their own affinity with it and their motivation for pursuing it. Lectures and scheduled meetings are, in principle, compulsory for all Youth, Education and Society students, but there is room for individual choices in the job market orientation component (eight hours). Examples of these options include Youth, Education and Society excursions, visits to a research or educational conference, or a lecture.

Students attend lectures concerning Juveniles and Law (1 EC, 28 hours) in order to meet the NVO's entry requirements after completing the Master’s programme. You will complete the year-long course with an individual reflection dossier (1 EC, 28 hours), primarily dedicated to reflecting on your own professional development. You will write a brief report about your study activities, including a reflection on the relevance and applicability of your internship, thesis and future professional profile (no more than four pages, excluding title sheet and appendices). The final version of your reflection dossier will be assessed by the coordinator using an assessment form.

W.M. van Londen-Barentsen', 'drs. B. Horjus', 'J.J. Endendijk, PhD', 'MSc M.C. Kesselring', 'prof. dr. M.J. de Haan', ""R.A. van 't Rood""]",,"Course goals

column3: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
• to be able to apply scientific knowledge in the role of academic professional in the field of Youth, Education and Society  researcher;
• to gain knowledge of the features of the organization in which you do your internship as well as the broader social context which is addressed by the organization;

• to be able to  reflect (in writing and orally) on the following areas concerning your internship on an academic level:    knowledge, analysis, intervention, method development, policy, collaboration and promoting expertise, personal and professional goals and ethics;
• to be able to develop a vision as an academic professional  in the field of Youth, Education and Society.

Starting point for the internship is the process acquiring an internship that suits your ambition in this academic field. In September preparatory course assignments include writing a personal and updated résumé and soliciting letter, with feedback process by peers and teacher and practicing your internship interview with feedback. The internship contains several phases with assignments, cumulating in your final internship report with your internship portfolio. Your internship supervisor at the organization as well as your university supervising internship teacher both will comment on the quality of you internship and reflection report to assess your quality of an academic professional.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: <div>

column9: Each student will carry out  an internship. The internship and thesis are closely linked in the programme, see under the course description of Youth, Education and Society 07: Thesis. The organization in which you do your internship and the issues with which it deals should be relevant to the field of the Youth, Education, and Society Master; this will be determined and approved by the internship coordinator. During the internship, you will gain practical experience at an institute or organization related to one of the programme's angles of approach. You could gain experience, for example, as a researcher, policy maker or project manager. Youth, Education and Society students do internships in a range of settings, including such organizations as:
• national or regional knowledge institutes (research and policy);
• umbrella, representative or quality assurance organisations of social services ;
• the research and development department of a large youth organisation or juvenile care organization (quality assurance policy);

Youth, Education and Society students conduct their internships from February until July (blocks 3 and 4). It is also possible to do your internship at  an organization outside the Netherlands, in this case the same applies for your research in most cases. Applications for internships are submitted during block 1. In block 2, students prepare for their internships under the supervision of a teacher. The online Youth, Education and Society internship database on Blackboard is available for students wishing to explore the options for doing an internship before the start of the academic year. Information will be available on our website.  . Students apply for an internship in one of the following two tracks:

Youth Policy, Education and Prevention is our ‘regular’ track, while International Development has a specific focus on International Development. The main difference between the tracks is the kind of social issues you are addressing in your internship and thesis (while course work is largely similar). Students in the regular track will mostly be working with social issues of Youth, Education and Society as related to moderns welfare states, while students who do our track International Development will focus on issues of Youth, Education and Society as related to International Development. For our regular track, we are working with National and local knowledge and policy organizations or research institutes, such as the Netherlands Youth Institute (NJI), the Verwey Jonker Institute, or the ministry of Education, culture and Science or the ministry of Health, Welfare and Sports. It is also possible to work with international organizations within this track.

For our track international Development, we are working with international partners involved in international aid, such as UNESCO, Oxfam Novib, Safe the Children or Edukans. In both tracks the possibility exists to do the internship outside of the Netherlands. Students have done their internships in both Africa, Latin America, Asia, as well as in Eastern Europe. While the programme offers internship options from our network, students might also bring in other organizations.

The purpose of an internship is to enable students to integrate their academic knowledge from the programme with practical skills. These skills will be advanced further by combining the internship with the course MOV5: Youth, Education and Society: Academic Professional.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course is taught in English. For Dutch speaking students, parts of the course may be offered in Dutch. See the course manual for further details.
• to gain knowledge of scientific research methods that can be applied to analyse issues in the field of Youth, Education & Society
• to be able to analyse a  problem in the field of Youth, Education & Society with the aid of relevant scientific theories and in cooperation with involved stakeholders in the field;

• to be able to apply relevant and suitable scientific research methods when analysing an issue in the field of Youth, Education & Society, and to report on this study in the form of an academic publication.

The course goal is to be able to individually write the Masterthesis based on scientific theories and research methods applied to an issue in the field of Youth, Education and Society. The assignment of the thesis proposal at the start of the course, the feedback by peers and the supervising teacher and several individual and group supervising meetings prepare the student to hand in the optimal final version of the thesis at the end of the course to be graded by two teachers.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The Master's thesis is the final assignment, in which students demonstrate their academic ability by carrying out independent scientific  research in the field of Youth, Education & Society . Students will develop  their ability:
• to carefully analyse socially-urgent issues in relation to the field of Youth, Education & Society , with the aid of the latest academic theories
• to independently collect and process empirical data;
• to deliver an accurate and accessible academic report on the subject.

In the Master’s programme  Youth, Education and Society you learn to use theoretical approaches that acknowledge the complexity of the social issues, as is the case with, for example, ecological or contextual  models. In general,  research is focused on issues of innovation, improvement or critical evaluation of existing  prevention strategies, interventions,  youth policy, and/or theory approaches. Students can do their research project either in the Netherlands or in other countries.

The research conducted for the Master’s thesis will, in principle, be carried out within or in close collaboration with the organization in which you do your internship. The reason for this link is to ensure that students can practice responding to practical social issues, with the aid of independent academic analysis and evaluation methods. The most suitable research method will depend on the research question, which is formulated in consultation with  the student, the internship organization, and the university supervisor.
• a classic descriptive study  or research that tests an hypothesis;
• a practical analysis in which the quality of a policy or an intervention is studied with a process evaluation and/or an effect study, based on scientific theories and research methods;
• a meta-analysis in which larger numbers of existing empirical studies are examined and compared;
• a  theoretical-analytical study in which a theoretical perspective itself is the subject of research.

Research projects are set up taking account of the various levels at which issues in the field of Youth, Education & Society can be influenced. In many cases, a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods (mixed methods) will be applied, depending on what is best applicable given the research questions and the time frame.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176093,2016,Nervous system,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. I.E.T. van den Berg'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course Nervous System has a regular and technical version.
During this course, the most important neurological illnesses are addressed.

The following aspects are discussed: clinical signs and symptoms, diagnostics, pathogenesis, etiology, epidemiology, disease progression and prognosis, and treatment.  The student must be able to correctly analyze and approach health problems, by either recommending treatment or by further referral. More goals established for course Nervous System can be found in the course handbook.
A strong emphasis is placed on self-study (ICT) based on the “Flipping the Classroom” model.

Every illness or group of illnesses will be addressed during an interactive lecture, with the aid of a patient diagnosed with the illness when possible. A work session on the discussed material will come the day after, or a few days after the lecture.  The students receive laboratory sessions on pathology, neuro-radiology, electromyography, and electro-encephalography. Two meet-the-expert sessions are scheduled for a question-and-answer meeting.
The course Nervous System is given in week 32 through 36 of year 2 (calendar weeks 15 through 19).
The course is based on the following sources:

column2: • Hijdra et al. Neurologie. Fourth or fifth ed
• Brain e.a. Aids to the examination of the peripheral nervous system, fourth edition

column1: Please also refer to the general textbook list
A written/digital test takes place twice a year (one regular test and one repeat).
More information about the assessment can be found in the course manual.

column3: Na afronding van de cursus kan de student:

column5: fundamentele ziekteprocessen (pathofysiologie) herkennen en karakteriseren;
farmacologische werkingsmechanismen (farmacokinetiek, -dynamiek) toepassen;
de manier waarop geneesmiddelen (met name biologicals) worden ontwikkeld, reproduceren, onderbouwen en beoordelen;
de dagelijkse praktijk in het medische bedrijf betrokken bij de toepassing en ontwikkeling van biotechnologische producten (apotheek, ziekenhuisafdelingen, researchafdeling, startup) onderkennen;
de medische manier van denken en handelen weergeven;
ethische dilemma’s die gepaard gaan met de ontwikkeling en toepassing van medicijnen onderscheiden en becommentariëren in debat;
een actueel ziektegebied en de bijbehorende life sciences-ontwikkelingen onderzoeken en weergeven via mondelinge presentatie en schriftelijk casusverslag.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Iedereen die gaat werken in het gebied van de life sciences, in welke positie dan ook, krijgt direct of indirect te maken met het medische bedrijf. Het is daarom van groot belang dat de studenten van het NW&I-track Life Sciences kennismaken met de medische manier van denken en handelen. Het doel van deze cursus is dan ook tweeledig: naast het bijbrengen van basale medische kennis op het gebied van pathofysiologie, farmacologie, oncologie, microbiologie, en geneesmiddel-ontwikkeling, ook het in de praktijk kennismaken met een aantal medische gebieden via gastcolleges en een bedrijfsbezoek. De gebieden die hierbij aan bod komen, zijn vooral die gebieden waar de medische biotechnologie thans erg actief is, zoals de therapeutische eiwitten en monoklonale antistoffen voor de behandeling van kanker, chronische ziekten en hormonale afwijkingen.
Academische vaardigheden: Schriftelijk rapporteren (casus), mondeling rapporteren (casus), mondelinge vaardigheid (debatteren).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het blok richt zich primair op de functie en dysfunctie van hersenen en ruggenmerg.  De student verwerft basisinzicht in de ontwikkeling, bouw en functie van het zenuwstelsel en in de principes van prikkelgeleiding en prikkeloverdracht. Er wordt ingegaan op de mogelijkheden om de neurotransmissie te beïnvloeden door middel van farmaca, op de aangrijpingspunten en de hoofd- en bijwerkingen van neuro- en psychofarmaca. In de loop van het blok leert de student om succesvol zowel somatische als psychische klachten en afwijkingen te duiden en de mogelijkheden van therapie te onderkennen

In dit blok wordt gebruik gemaakt van verschillende werkvormen. Er zijn 18 hoorcolleges, 8 patiëntdemonstraties, 4 practica, 7 werkgroepen/werkcolleges, 3 interactieve colleges en 3 meet the expert’-bijeenkomsten. In het blokboek staat per week aangegeven welk onderwijs georganiseerd wordt en hoeveel tijd voor de zelfstudies is  ingeroosterd.

ZHB I is het vierde blok van jaar 1.  Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging I vormt samen met de tweedejaars blokken ZHB II en III een thema in de bacheloropleiding, omdat de functies van de betrokken orgaansystemen nauw met elkaar samenhangen. In dit blok staan de hersenen centraal, in ZHB II de beweging en in ZHB III de zintuigen. De praktijk van dit thema zal de student tegenkomen in blok en link blauw.
Het blok is gebaseerd op de volgende bronnen:
-    blokboek Zintuigen, hersenen, beweging I en daarin genoemde literatuur
het blok wordt aan het eind door middel van essay- en meerkeuzevragen getoetst. Op blackboard kan de student zichzelf toetsen aan de hand van daar geplaatste vragen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het blok Zintuigen, Hersenen en Beweging II gaat over de bouw en functie van de onderdelen van het Steun- en Bewegingsstelsel (SBS), over hun onderlinge relatie en over problemen die zich kunnen voordoen in één van de onderdelen of als het samenspel niet goed meer verloopt.
De farmacologie leerlijn is in dit blok verwerkt. Het accent ligt op de farmacologie en het voorschrijven van NSAID’s
Aan het einde van het blok zal de student kennis hebben van de normale bouw en het normale functioneren en van de klinische stoornissen en beperkingen van het SBS.

In het blok ZHB II wordt gebruik gemaakt van verschillende werkvormen. Er zijn 10 hoorcolleges, 3 patiëntdemonstraties, 5 interactieve colleges, 6 dissectiepractica, 6 werkgroepen en 2 meet the expert-bijeenkomsten.

Het blok Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging II sluit aan op het blok Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging I (Centraal Zenuwstelsel). In het blok Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging III wordt op de verkregen kennis aangesloten. Ook zijn er keuzecursussen in jaar 2 die goed aansluiten op ZHB II.
Het blok is gebaseerd op de volgende bronnen:
-    Blokboek Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging II en de daarin genoemde literatuur
De toetsing bestaat uit een toets die over de gehele stof gaat.
Contactpersoon en informatie: dr. T. A. P. Roeling, T.A.P.Roeling@umcutrecht.nl
Je moet ingeschreven staan voor de volgende opleiding:
Er moet voldaan zijn aan de cursus :

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit blok ligt een belangrijk accent op de zintuigen. Anatomie en fysiologie van het hoofd-halsgebied en de huid komen ook aan de orde. Zintuiglijke waarnemingen zoals gehoor, evenwicht, visus, reuk en smaak worden behandeld evenals de belangrijkste stoornissen op deze terreinen. Ook de pathologie van de huid en slijmvliezen in het hoofd-halsgebied komt aan bod. Tevens is er aandacht voor de Psychiatrie. Het thema hiervan is ontwikkeling. Centraal staat daarbij steeds de  gestoorde ontwikkeling, die zich ook op volwassen leeftijd kan manifesteren.  De onderwerpen zijn: kinder- en jeugdpsychiatrie en persoonlijkheidsstoornissen
In dit blok wordt gebruik gemaakt van verschillende werkvormen. Er zijn 13 hoorcolleges,  9 werkgroepen, 3 interactieve colleges en 5 practica; 4 dissectiepractica anatomie en 1 histologiepracticum.

Het blok ZHB III is een blok in jaar 2 en vormt samen met de blokken ZHB I (jaar 1), ZHB II (jaar 2) het thema Zintuigen, hersenen en beweging in de bacheloropleiding. De praktijk van dit thema zal de student vooral tegenkomen in blok en link geel en blok en link paars (jaar 2 en 3 van de master opleiding).
Het blok is gebaseerd op de volgende bronnen:
-    blokboek  ZHB III en de daarin genoemde literatuur

Dit blok kent één eindtoets die aan het eind van blokweek 5 wordt gehouden. In de toetsing ligt de nadruk op het toepassen van verworven kennis, inzichten en vaardigheden, vooral gericht op situaties die van belang zijn voor de latere beroepsuitoefening.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The course Brain, Senses and Movement IV serves as preparation for the internships in the UMCU or in one of the affiliated teaching hospitals. Your first acquaintance with Clinical Neurology has been a few years ago. The course serves to refresh your knowledge of Clinical Neurology and Neuroanatomy. Besides, you will also need to train your clinical skills. Ample attention will be given to neurological history taking and physical examination, and you will learn how to localize neurological signs and symptoms to specific sites in the central or the peripheral nervous system.
To ensure that you will practice and apply what you have learnt during the course in the internship, the maximum time between course and internship is limited to 6 weeks.

Please see the course book BSM IV and the general book list for mandatory and recommended literature, as well as the available literature in the study landscape. Further information on course content is available on Blackboard.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Het blok ZHB Psych Ma 1dient ter voorbereiding op de coschappen Psychiatrie. Het blok ZHB Psych Ma 1 bestaat uit interactieve werkcolleges waarin de belangrijkste psychiatrische ziekten met de specifieke symptomatologie, klinisch beeld, diagnostiek en differentiaal diagnostiek, behandeling en prognose worden behandeld. Daarnaast is er ruimte voor zelfstudie, en het maken van de e-module ‘Psychiatrisch Onderzoek’. Tijdens de colleges zijn er patiëntendemonstraties waarbij het accent ligt op gesprekstechnieken en het leren en doen van psychiatrisch onderzoek. Daarnaast is er een ochtend onderwijs in wetenschappelijk onderzoek in de psychiatrie waarbij de mogelijkheid bestaat om zich te oriënteren op een eventuele wetenschappelijke stage binnen de afdeling psychiatrie.
Interactieve werkcolleges, zelfstudie, e-learning middels e-module.  Er is een aanwezigheidsverplichting voor het onderwijs in ZHB Psych Ma 1.
Plaats van het blok in het curriculum

Het blok ZHB Psych Ma 1gaat vooraf aan het coassistentschap Psychiatrie. Het blok duurt twee weken en wordt per studiejaar  twaalf maal gegeven voor steeds twee groepen van ongeveer twaalf studenten. De periode tussen het behalen van de toets voor ZHB Psych Ma 1 en het coschap Psychiatrie mag maximaal 3 maanden zijn.
Zie het blokboek ZHB Psych Ma 1 en de standaard boekenlijst voor verplichte en aanbevolen literatuur, evenals voor de beschikbare literatuur in het studielandschap.

ZHB Psych Ma 1 wordt afgesloten met een toets die gehaald moet worden om toegang tot het coschap te verkrijgen.  Daarnaast moet er voldaan zijn aan de regels omtrent aanwezigheid zoals beschreven in het blokboek.
Coördinator: mw.dr. M. Kromkamp, via het onderwijssecretariaat psychiatrie: L.vanOudenaarden@umcutrecht.nl of E.J.Polak-Vedder@umcutrecht.nl

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/174005,2016,Zoo Conservation Biology,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. J.J.M. Pereboom'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After completing the module the student is able to:
• applicate biological principles for zoo conservation
• discuss management in field conservation programs
• give a lecture on a topic of zoo conservation

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Conservation Biology is a relatively new multidisciplinary field in biology which focuses on biological principles and their applications for the preservation of species and habitats, biodiversity conservation in general and the maintenance of equilibrium within ecosystems. It represents a fusion of relevant ideas from ecology, population biology, genetics, biogeography, behaviour and a number of applied disciplines such as wildlife management and forestry. Zoo Conservation Biology specifically approaches this broad field of research from a zoo perspective, and this course will mainly focus on areas of interest that are related to small population management in captive settings and in field conservation programs.
This course is part of the Master in Environmental Biology at Utrecht University specialization programme Behavioural Ecology.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De zorgstage vormt een eerste kennismaking met de dagelijkse praktijk van ziekenhuis, verpleeghuis en public healthinstelling. De student verdiept zich in het aanbod van klachten, problemen en ziekten in de gezondheidszorg, de gevolgen van een chronische of ernstige aandoening voor patiënten en hun omgeving en de doelstellingen en werkwijze van de zorgverleners. Tevens doet de student ervaring op in basale professionele vaardigheden in de omgang met patiënten en collega’s. Ten slotte leert de student over eigen sterke en zwakke vaardigheden in de omgang met patiënten en collega’s te reflecteren en persoonlijke leerdoelstellingen voor de verdere opleiding te preciseren.

Voorafgaand aan de zorgstage vindt een college over infectiepreventie plaats en een college over de organisatie van de gezondheidszorg, professioneel gedrag, vertrouwelijkheid van patiëntinformatie, competentiegrenzen en het hanteren van het ziekte belevingsmodel in een casusbeschrijving. In een StudieReflectiebijeenkomst wordt aandacht besteed aan het opstellen van (algemene en persoonlijke) leerdoelstellingen. Daarnaast vindt een training van praktische vaardigheden, zoals tillen en wassen van patiënten, plaats. De stage duurt twee weken. De student wordt ingedeeld in een verpleeghuis, ziekenhuis of public healthinstelling. Direct na de stage levert de student een schriftelijk stageverslag in. Kort daarna volgt een StudieReflectiebijeenkomst waarin ervaringen in de vorm van een stellingenspel en discussies worden uitgewisseld.

Het voorbereidende onderwijs vindt plaats in de eerste twee blokken van het studiejaar (september en oktober). De zorgstage zelf in week 44 en 45  van het kalenderjaar (eind oktober en begin november).

column2: • Volksgezondheid en gezondheidszorg door Mackenbach en Stronks, 6de druk. Reed Business.

column1: De student wordt beoordeeld door een stagebegeleider op de stageplek met betrekking tot Professioneel Gedrag, en krijgt tevens een beoordeling voor een schriftelijk verslag door een docent van het UMC Utrecht. Beide onderdelen moeten voldoende zijn om een voldoende eindbeoordeling te kunnen halen. Zie het blokboek Zorgstage voor details van de toetsing.
Contactpersoon en informatie: Mw. N.M. van den Berg en/of mw. M.B.Berk: zorgstage-examinator@umcutrecht.nl, of via secretariaat zorgstage: zorgstage-admin@umcutrecht.nl
Je moet ingeschreven staan voor de volgende opleiding:

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De fysische, sociale, politieke en economische ontwikkelingen in Zuid-Amerika te begrijpen, beschrijven, analyseren, verklaren en bediscussiëren.
• Overeenkomsten en verschillen te identificeren, met betrekking tot bottum-up en top-down ontwikkelingen in verschillende geografische contexten binnen het Zuid-Amerikaanse continent.
• De ontwikkeling op een bepaald schaalniveau kunnen identificeren en beschrijven, en de doorwerking tussen en op verschillende schaalniveaus (van lokaal naar nationaal of vice versa) inzien.

• Een probleemstelling op het gebied van één onderwerp kunnen formuleren en deze ook kunnen beantwoorden in een zelfstandig te schrijven paper, waarin zowel fysisch geografische als sociaalgeografische elementen aan bod komen.
• Een (peer)review te schrijven over een paper waardoor geoefend wordt in een noodzakelijke beroepsvaardigheid: het beoordelen van de concepten van collega’s en het geven van feedback daarop.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus is in de vorm van een e-module, die grotendeels op afstand en zelfstandig wordt doorlopen. Inschrijven voor E-modules is mogelijk via dit formulier. Inschrijven tijdens de na-inschrijving is niet mogelijk.

De cursus is opgebouwd rondom acht thema’s in de Zuid-Amerikaanse context. Elke week staat er één thema centraal dat belicht wordt vanuit een fysisch, politiek, sociaal of economisch oogpunt. Door de e-lectures te bekijken en het lezen van de (inter)nationale literatuur doe je je kennis op. Aan het eind van elke week wordt het thema afgesloten met een multiple-choice toets online (via Blackboard).

Parallel naast de thema’s schrijf je een individueel paper. De onderwerpen worden aangedragen, maar je formuleert zelf een meer specifieke probleemstelling. In dit individuele paper belicht je het onderwerp vanuit zowel een sociaal- als fysisch perspectief en betrek je de literatuur die in de cursus gebruikt wordt (en kennis uit de e-lectures). Tussentijds ontvang je feedback op een conceptversie, waarna je de kans hebt om je paper te verbeteren voordat je de definitieve versie inlevert.
Thema’s die in de cursus aan bod komen:

column2: • Brazilië: een sociaal geografische visie op de demografie, cultureel en economie van het land
• Fysisch geografisch perspectief op het klimaat en diversiteit van landschappen in Zuid Amerika.

column1: Deze cursus is ingangseis voor de Educatieve Master Lerarenopleiding aardrijkskunde: w.b.t. het wegwerken van sociaal geografische vakdeficiënties.</body>

column3: In deze stage zult u kennis maken met de hoofdtaken en de organisatie/randvoorwaarden in de ziekenhuis apotheek. Na deze stage zal de student een indruk hebben gekregen van de wijze waarop in de stage apotheek invulling wordt gegeven aan de beschreven taken en organisatorische aspecten.
In het blokboek staand de leerdoelen in uitgebreidere vorm beschreven, zie http://vkc.library.uu.nl/vkc/upper/education/internships/kennismakingsstages.aspx.</body>

column4: De kennismakingsstage bestaat uit een stage van 1 week in een ziekenhuisapotheek. De student gaat inzicht krijgen in de relatie tussen theorie en praktijk, waarop voortgebouwd kan worden tijdens hoofdstages in het laatste jaar van de studie.
Tevens helpt de kennismakingsstage een duidelijker beeld te vormen over de richting waarin de student zich verder kan ontplooien tijdens het vervolg van de masteropleiding.

Er kan alleen stage worden gevolgd in een UPPER opleidingsapotheek, die in de betreffende periode plaats heeft voor een stagiair. Actuele en praktische informatie hierover wordt via Blackboard bekend gemaakt. Daarnaast wordt in blok FA-402 een korte inleiding verzorgd over deze kennismakingsstage, door de stagecoördinator mw. Blom.
Voor meer informatie zie Blackboard en http://upstage.science.uu.nl/.
De stage wordt afgesloten met de inlevering van een overzicht van werkzaamheden tijdens de kennismakingsweek en een door de stageverlener ondertekend beoordelingsformulier

De beoordeling van deze stage telt niet mee voor het vaststellen van het judicium "cum laude". Kennismakingsstages worden alleen als ‘behaald’ doorgegeven. In Osiris komt daarom een ‘v’ te staan, ook als het eindoordeel ‘goed’ is.

column4: In deze stage zal de student kennis maken met de hoofdtaken en de organisatie/randvoorwaarden in de openbare apotheek. Na deze stage zal de student een indruk hebben gekregen van de wijze waarop in de openbare apotheek invulling wordt gegeven aan de beschreven taken en organisatorische aspecten.
In het blokboek staan de leerdoelen in uitgebreidere vorm beschreven. Zie: http://vkc.library.uu.nl/vkc/upper/education/Internships/kennismakingsstages.aspx

column4: De kennismakingsstage bestaat uit een stage in een openbare apotheek van 5 weken. De student gaat inzicht krijgen in de relatie tussen theorie en praktijk, waarop voortgebouwd kan worden tijdens de hoofdstages in het laatste jaar van de studie.
Tevens helpt de kennismakingsstage een duidelijker beeld te vormen over de richting waarin u zich verder kan ontplooien tijdens het vervolg van uw masteropleiding.
Tijdens de stage vindt er een onderwijsbijeenkomst in de vorm van een terugkomdag; deze bijeenkomst is een verplicht onderdeel van de stage.

Er kan alleen stage worden gevolgd in een UPPER opleidingsapotheek, die in de betreffende periode plaats heeft voor een stagiair. De stagecoördinator Mw. Blom verzorgt informatie over de apotheekstages en plaatsing tijdens inleidingen in het begin van de Masterfase (in blok Fa-401 en Fa-403).
Voor meer informatie zie Blackboard en http://upstage.science.uu.nl/.

De stage wordt afgesloten met een stagedossier (zie ook het blokboek) met daarin opgenomen een beoordeling door de stageverlener. De stage wordt beoordeeld door een stagedocent, die daarbij gebruik maakt van het ingeleverde stagedossier. De student is ervoor verantwoordelijk dat dit dossier voldoet aan de gestelde eisen die in het blokboek vermeld staan.

De beoordeling van deze stage telt niet mee voor het vaststellen van het judicium "cum laude". Kennismakingsstages worden alleen als ‘behaald’ doorgegeven. In Osiris komt daarom een ‘v’ te staan, ook als het eindoordeel ‘goed’ is.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182481,2017,'Heritage': Dynamics of Collections,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. M.R. Bouquet', 'dr. T. Zakula']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: engage with debates about the meanings and uses of the term ‘heritage’,
synthesize interdisciplinary approaches to 21st century heritage and make active use of scholarly skills,
explain the formation and evolution of the historic monument, collections, and heritage, informed by study in the fields of Art History, Anthropology and Science,
analyze some of the dynamics of 21st heritage: globalization, expansion, collection management,
apply their knowledge to real-life situations regarding monuments, collections, and different forms of heritage,
integrate interdisciplinary scholarship on heritage and collections into the core of their liberal arts and sciences education,
realize their own research paper departing from a focus on one or more of the dynamics of heritage,
write their research findings in the form of a visually informed research paper.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Cross-listed with SSC. Track finisher for Anthropology if UCSSCANT23 and UCHUMHAR22 have been completed as well.

This course takes a broad, comparative approach to the historical development of heritage while going into depth through a range of case studies, both European and non-European. From the rise of the historic monument and expanding scope of Renaissance collections; to the classification and inventory of national antiquities in the 17th and 18th centuries. The founding of national museums, whether commercially and scientifically-based, as with the British Museum (1759), or according to the revolutionary model of the Louvre Museum (1793), reflected core values of the Enlightenment: democracy, rationality and knowledge marked a new era of citizenship – for both subjects and objects. The vandalism unleashed by the French Revolution engendered efforts to conserve and classify as patrimoine royal assets otherwise vulnerable to destruction. Nineteenth-century restoration debates give insight into the ruptured sense of time perpetrated by the industrial revolution. Ethnographic collecting attempted to preserve a record of human groups whose arts and culture, it was believed, would disappear under colonial rule.  The 20th-century development of international professional organizations, conventions and the creation of new categories of heritage, such as industrial, natural and intangible, reflect the unprecedented expansion but also the frictions generated by heritage.

The course examines how and why these shifts took place by engaging with scholarly literature and debates in art history, history of science, and anthropology; and by means of case studies. The excursion to Brugge, Belgium in the mid-term break to visit museums and meet professionals adds a further dimension to the student’s knowledge of practical aspects of contemporary heritage institutions including collection management, conservation, research, exhibition and education.

The course is divided into three content sections: the first two before mid-term, and the third after mid-term, each with its own written assignment. The final weeks of the semester will be devoted to writing a research essay on a topic of the student’s own choice. There will be a number of plenary sessions to ensure course cohesion throughout. There will be small assignments to support the research process and individual meetings to support the writing process of the term paper throughout the semester. The optional excursion is highly recommended to those who plan to undertake an internship.

<body>Studenten maken kennis met actuele debatten over erfgoed en identiteit. De cursus neemt een interdisciplinaire aanpak; methodologie en theorie uit verschillende disciplines uit de sociale en humane wetenschappen zullen worden gemobiliseerd om het heden van het verleden zowel cultureel, economisch en politiek te vatten.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

NB 1 Deze cursus zal studenten vertrouwd maken met centrale theoretische concepten, methoden en voorbeelden uit de erfgoedstudies. Door inzichten uit de antropologie, geschiedenis en antropologie moet hen toelaten om op een interdisciplinaire manier erfgoed en publieksgeschiedenis te bestuderen in de 21ste eeuw. Een eeuw waar niet enkel geschiedenis wordt gebruikt door de natiestaat bij het creëren en legitimeren van collectieve gemeenschapen. Ook multinationals en internationale organisaties gebruiken vandaag de dag cultureel erfgoed om hun neoliberale agenda’s en diplomatiek netwerken te normaliseren. Doorheen de verschillende lessen en voorbeelden zullen we niet alleen onderzoeken hoe contemporaine socioculturele processen, institutionele structuren en identiteitspolitiek de beleving en bewaring van het verleden in het heden beïnvloedt. Door erfgoed en cultureel geheugen als een culturele tekst te zien die hermeneutisch kan worden ontleed, zullen we ook bestuderen hoe de studie van erfgoedpolitiek innovatieve inzichten kan verschaffen over het culturele heden.
b. het analyseren van concrete (erfgoed-)instellingen in het binnen- en buitenland</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This seminar provides an examination of the central philosophical texts and arguments of one or more key figures in 20th-Century German (and Austrian) philosophy. Students will gain insight into the wider context of the texts studies and an understanding of the arguments for and against the positions taken.  They will also develop their own interpretation and assessment of the texts examined.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the German-speaking world, the 20th century was a period of enormously diverse and fruitful philosophical activity: the phenomenological and hermeneutical tradition of Husserl, Heidegger, and Gadamer; the analytical philosophy of Wittgenstein and the Vienna Circle; the Frankfurt School tradition from Horkheimer and Adorno to Habermas and Honneth; and the influential work of Hannah Arendt.  Each year, this seminar will focus on one or two philosophers, focusing on particularly influential texts.
This course is for RMA students in the Graduate School of Humanities and students in the History and Philosophy of Science. Students of other MA-programmes, please contact the Course Coordinator.
Interested M.A. exchange students with a strong background in philosophy may qualify to take the course; however, they should first contact the RMA Philosophy coordinator:  j.h.anderson@uu.nl

1.          Learn       to       apply       and       extend       knowledge       and       skills       gained       during       theory       classes.
2.    Learn to translate business management problems into a clear problem statement and relevant sub questions.
3.    Learn to design and conduct the practical and theoretical research needed to answer the questions.
4.    Learn to analyse and interpret results.
5.    Learn to write a business report with concrete conclusions and recommendations.
6.    Learn to present the outcomes of the report to an audience of specialists and non-specialists.

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

To really understand how       things       work       outside       the       university,       an       internship       in       a       company       or       institute       is       obligatory.       Preferably       the       topic       of       the       internship       is       a       combination       of       both       business       and       science.       Before       the       start       of       the       internship       a       clear       formulation       of       a       problem,       which       will       be       the       subject       of       investigation,       has       to       be       approved       by       the       internship       coordinator.       The       internship       includes       practical       work,       and       a       report       (in       total       around       5       months),       for       instance       with       a       consultancy       firm       advising       multinationals       on       their       research       policies,       or       in       a       small       biotech       start-up       company       working       on       business       development.       A       supervisor       from       the       University       should       be       involved       in       guiding       you       through       this       business       internship.
